text:
I was leary of making this without first pre-cooking the meatballs, but this is by far the best spaghetti and meatballs I have ever made.  The meatballs ended up a nice brown color, they were not over cooked and I think putting them in before browning allowed some of the meat flavor to seep into the sauce.  I great recipe.

text:
Five star rating is based on the following changes.  Instead of using all ground beef, I opted to use a combination of ground pork and ground beef (12 oz ground beef, 4 oz ground pork) -instead of plain bread crumbs, I used pre-seasoned breadcrumbs, I increased the parmesan cheese to 4 oz. 

With the sauce, instead of using 2 (28 oz) cans of whole tomatoes, I used 1 (28 oz can) of whole tomatoes, and then two smaller cans (14 oz) of crushed tomatoes.  After simmering the sauce, I ran half of it through the blender to make it smoother.  I also added a small can of tomato sauce in addition to the tomato paste, plus for added flavour I added 1 tsp italian seasoning, 1/2 tsp basil, and 1 tsp garlic powder.

YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!

text:
This was absolutly the most wonderful spaghetti. This was my first time making homemade spaghetti. I work long hours and don't have time at night to make a 2 hour meal, so what I did was use my slow cooker. In the morning i sauteed my onion and garlic, combined it with all the ingredience including half a can of tomato sauce for extra liquid since it tends to lose some in a slow cooker. Had my husband turn the cooker on low at his lunch, so the sauce cooked about 6 1/2 hours. one hour before the sauce was done, he put the meat balls in. We did end up adding the extra half a can of sauce just for liquid, but the flavor was amazing. By using the slow cooker for us working cooks, it was nice to come home to a ready made meal and good as this.

text:
This sauce was very easy to make and quite delicious.  I do agree with some reviews that the meatballs were a bit bland, but to each his own, my husband liked them.  I will never use bottled sauce again, that's for sure.  Note:  to others who who mentionned they substituted turkey or other poultry for ground beef  ...  you are never supposed to use breadcrumbs, that type of meat is quite dry, breadcrumbs only makes it worse!

text:
For Celeste, who found the meatballs too dry, may I suggest adding 1/2 cup of water, or milk, or tomato sauce to the meatballs?  The eggs will bind them, but not make them moister - adding liquid makes them exquisitely tender and juicy.  Also, if you want a lighter meatball, substitute oatmeal for the breadcrumbs - measure it first, then run it briefly in the blender so you won't have any big bits in the meatballs.  I added 1.5 tsp oregano and 3 tsp basil; added 1 tsp seasoned salt, 1 medium green pepper.  I was very, very happy with the sauce.  Put it into a 250 degree oven while I cooked other stuff, for about 2 hours,it was wonderful.  :D

text:
This is a great recipe - although I did alter it a bit from the beginning.  Do brown the meat balls first, before adding them to sauce.  I think this adds a little flavor.  I also spiced up the meatballs with some stand-by italian spices (basic, oregano, etc.) and I upped the garlic (to taste).  Also, I used crackers (pounded or processed to crumbs) in place of bread crumbs, and used a little less than called for.  This made a very solid and yummy meatball - for those who have "spongey" meatballs.  For those who used store-bought sauce with the meatballs - nothing compares with this sauce!

text:
I simply loved this recipe as it resembled on of my own.  In the meatballs, I used only 1/2 lb ground beef and 1/2 lb ground sausage; 1/2 cup crushed buttery crackers i.e. Ritz; 1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese, garlic powder toi taste, 2 Tbsp chopped onion, 1 Tbsp Bell pepper, 1 Tbsp chopped celery and 1/2 pkg hamburger or meatloaf seasoning mix.  I prepared my meatballs and cooked them in the oven on a sheet pan for 20 minutes at 350 degrees.  Then added them to my sauce.  My Sauce included 1/2 stalk chopped celery, 1/4 chopped bell pepper 1 Tbsp sugar and rather than 2 28 ounce cans whole tomatoes, I used 1 ea. 28 oz can Crushed Tomatoes and 1 ea. 28 ounce can Tomato Puree.  This eliminated the lumpy tomato chunks.  I eliminated the tomato paste altogether.  I reduced my cooking time to 30 minutes and then 30 minutes after adding the meatballs.

text:
If you use veal and pork with your ground beef (you can buy meatloaf mix) your meatballs will be so moist and soft.  I know from years of cooking with my grandmother and mother - trust me.  My grandmother was from Naples, Italy (right off that boat!) and taught my mother (who was German) everything about Italian cooking - she wanted my father to eat like he was still at home with her!!  Plus, brown your meatballs before you add them to your sauce.  And, make sure to cook that sauce (on low -  simmer it) for at least 2 hours or until that "raw" smell goes away.  All of a sudden, your kitchen will smell like an Italian restaurant - that's when you are sure that sauce is cooked - we call it gravy - that's one way to tell a genuine Italian!  Enjoy -  your recipe just needs these few small changes/additions - you are on the right track!!

text:
This is one of an almost infinite number of very good "Italian" spaghetti tomato-sauce recipes. I am always intrigued when the recipe calls for "Parmesan" cheese ("Parmigiano Reggiano" cheese)- the supposed ultimate in Italian grating cheeses. Occasionally, because of almost status-symbolism, it has been referred to as the "Yuppie" cheese. In reality, a significant percentage (perhaps a majority) of Americans of Italian descent use imported Pecorino Romano cheese (I prefer the Locatelli brand)in their pasta sauces. This very tasty and usually much more reasonably priced cheese has been described as somewhat salty, spicy, sharp, and tangy. It is a sheep cheese that becomes increasingly robust with age. Try it when a pasta tomato-sauce recipe calls for Parmigiano Reggiano (Parmesan) cheese. You may be pleasantly surprised - certainly, your wallet will be.

My thanks to the person who gave us this recipe; it's great, and makes a delicious spaghetti supper! text:
I have NEVER liked spaghetti & meatballs but one night my boyfriend asked me to make it for him and thanks to your DELICIOUS recipe, I am now a spaghetti & meatballs LOVER! I follow this recipe exactly except I use Panko bread-crumbs in the meatballs, which are the bread-crumbs I prefer for everything. This recipe does take a long time but if you plan ahead and follow it exactly- its SOOO WORTH IT!!! Plan at least 2 hours  of cook time and get the sauce going first- instead of doing the meatballs first like the recipe suggests. You have to cook the sauce for 90 minutes so you might as well do the meatballs while the sauce is cooking rather than doing them before you even start the sauce, taking on another 15-20 minutes to your entire cook time. This recipe tastes SOOO FRESH and authentic, thank you again!! I wish I could give you more than 5 stars!

text:
I have a suggestion: with regards to the dried parsley....I always use about 1/4 bunch of large sprigs of parsley(stems and all) of fresh parsley...this is a tip I got from my mother in law who got it from a lovely Italian neighbor of hers years ago.  Not sure of the exact difference, but her sauce recipe is to die for.  Simmer the parsley in the sauce until ready to serve, then scoop the pieces out of the sauce.  They claim it is essential to the sauce!!! Dry parsley has no taste in their (and mine) opinions!

text:
I made this for my family during the holidays - I received rave reviews. I however improvised on a few things. I added 1 lb. ground pork (along with 2 lbs ground beef), used more cheese and a seasoned breadcrumb mix. I also added real garlic instead of powder, and used Italian seasoning with a dash extra of basil. I also added a little milk. After I rolled them, I put them in casserole dishes in one layer and baked them uncovered at 350Â°F for about 20 min. - until browned. Meanwhile I had the sauce simmering for about an hour (I started the sauce first on the stove top). In addition to the whole tomatoes, I added 2 cans of tomato sauce and 1 can tomato paste. I didn't use bay leaf but added the Italian seasoning again. I poured the sauce over the meatballs, covered and returned back to the oven for about 20 -30 minutes. Turned out fabulous and everyone said they were wonderful - even the kids. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Rating based on the following changes:

SAUCE:  BLENDED the whole tomatoes for a smoother sauce.  Added 1 stalk chopped celery, 1 tsp italian seasoning, 1/2 tsp basil, 1 tsp garlic powder.  Doubled the tomato paste (13 oz can).

MEATBALLS:  Used ground steak instead of store bought ground beef.  Added 1/2 cup milk, 3/4 cup minced onion, 1 tsp of onion powder, 1 1/2 tsp of italian seasoning.  Doubled the garlic powder (1/4 tsp) and eggs (2 eggs).  Omitted the parmasan cheese.  Simmer meatballs for at least 1 hour (they were still pink after 30 min).  Meatballs were mushy, so I would recommend browning or cooking in the oven for a firmer meatball.

A GREAT recipe if you make these changes.  It was my first homemade sauce attempt and tastes better the next day.  Even after freezing, it tasted great.  Just add some of the pasta water to it and some salt, and it's perfect.

After making a different sauce recipe, I am definitely returning to this one.  Just make sure to blend the whole tomatoes if you prefer a smooth but thick sauce.

text:
Delicious!  I doubled the recipe and used 1 lb ground beef and 1 lb ground pork, which makes all the difference in my opinion. I used 2-28oz cans of whole San Marzano tomatoes, and 2-28oz cans of crushed tomatoes. I sauteed the onion and garlic then transferred to my crock pot with the other ingredients and set on low for 7 hours. I also used 3/4 cup of Progresso Italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of the fresh bread crumbs. I never follow a recipe to make sauce and meatballs, but this is great, and my changes are because of personal preference. Instead of the basil, an Italian seasoning blend would work just great. Wonderful, classic meatball and sauce recipe! Thanks for sharing :)

text:
I have made this twice & yum, yum, yum!! It is pretty easy to make & it tastes like it takes a lot longer. I use a lot more garlic cloves & onion only because we love them both! I also use a 28 oz can of crushed or diced tomatoes instead of the whole ones & use a big 28 oz of tomato sauce. I put extra garlic & pepper in the meatballs too, along with 1/2 c milk. I do let the sauce simmer longer than 30 min with the meatballs, just to be safe! But my two teen stepsons who are picky as picky can come, LOVED it & said they had never eaten any spaghetti & meatballs so good! My husband raved over it also which is rare because normally he just says, "oh that was good, thank you" I made it again last night & my brother was over for dinner & he cleaned his plate & took some home after saying yum it was! Great recipe with few modifications.

Very good recipe--my husband wanted a spaghetti dinner for his birthday and everyone enjoyed it.  1/2009 Update--the meatballs turn out tastier when 1 tsp of both basil & oregano are added.  Also, I roll them smaller, about 1-1/2 inches and cook them in the sauce for about 45 minutes.  Use 93/7 lean ground beef and you won't have any worries about excess grease ; ).

text:
This recipe was amazing and easy & quick enough to make for dinner after work. My husband and I loved it! I only made a few changes to the recipe. I used two 6-ounce cans of tomato paste and I used crushed tomatoes instead of whole. I also added 1 tsp. of oregano and 1/4 cup of red wine (merlot) to the sauce half an hour before it was finished. As the recipe says, the meatballs do not need to be fried or baked prior to being added to the sauce. They cooked thoroughly, retained their shape and were moist and delicious. I'll never try another sauce or meatball recipe again. Thank you, Jeremy!

country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe for spaghetti sauce and have made it several times now. Very flavorful and easy to make.  I followed the suggestions of many other reviewers. 

For the meatballs: 1. I used seasoned vs plain breadcrumbs and I let the breadcrumbs soak in about 3/4c of milk BEFORE adding them to the meat. This makes the meatballs tender and moist. 2. I doubled the amount of parmesan cheese.  

For the sauce: 1. I didn't have whole peeled tomatoes on hand, so I used crushed tomatoes instead. 2. I added to small cans of tomato sauce which gave the sauce a very thick, rich body.  3. Instead of seasoning with just the basil, I used italian seasoning which made the taste PERFECT. Everyone loved the recipe, will make again and again.

text:
This is a good recipe. There are different Italians as they come from different parts of Italy so things are made differently. With that in mind, I will add my two cents in on this recipe. First, I NEVER use sugar or Bay Leaf. I also use CRUSHED TOMATO using more GARLIC and more BASIL. With the meatballs I add 1/2 lb. GROUND PORK to the 1 lb. GROUND BEEF. I do not use the "cheap" meats ever. If one buys cheap, end results will be cheap. I bake my meatballs in the oven to cook them. Some people prefer meatballs on the side. Add Parmesan cheese to the meatballs also. Maybe 1/4 cup to above meat amounts. With that in mind, enjoy!

I made my sauce in the crock pot. It is great on hectic days. Cook the onions and garlic in a small sauce pan, Add to crock pot when done. Place meatballs in botton of crock pot add your ingredients. I added an extra 28 oz can diced tomatoes. Cook on high for 5 hours. I removed the meatballs, and took a sub. blender to the sauce to create a smooth sauce added the meatballs back and cooked another 30 minutes. YUM Makes alot so I will try freezing the rest to enjoy later.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have been making this exact sauce for about 5 years now and it never fails to turn out great.  I do substitute Italian seasoning for the basil and I do sometimes add any additional ingredients such as ground beef, ground sausage, peppers, mushrooms, celery, zucchini, carrots and squash instead of the meatballs for a chunkier sauce.  I usually add about a teaspoon of crushed red pepper too for that bit of bite.  As far as the meatballs go, to get the best flavor from them; mix up the meat mixture the night before you plan on eating them and let the mixture sit in the fridge overnight, you will be amazed the difference it makes!  I do have my own recipe for meatballs but mixing it up the night before is a MUST.  If your sauce turned out sour tasting, it was probably from not letting the sauce cook long enough after you added the tomato paste.

text:
good starting recipe. we use romano cheese in the meatballs, and fresh garlic and bread soaked in milk for moist meatballs. for sauce, fresh garlic, onions, EVOO, puree and paste, s&p, sugar, dried basil and oregano, red wine and pinch of baking soda to ease the acid from the tomatoes. this sauce cooks for about 5-6 hours on low and stirring often or it will stick and burn, even in nonstick pot. and reseason about 2 hours before done. s&p, basil, oregano, and top off with EVOO and more "homemade red wine" if you have it. this comes from mom and grandmom, from naples, and grandpop from scilly. all excellent cooks. can't give recipies, we never measure, cook to taste only.

I've made this recipe at least 3 times and have been asked for the recipe by so many people.  The only changes I made were to use Italian sausage in place of the ground beef and I always soak my bread crumbs in milk and squeeze the milk out before I put them in the meatball mixture; this step will guaranty very moist meatballs.  The total 2 hour simmer time is essential; it is what makes this sauce so rich and intense with basic ingredients.

Fantastic! MADE THE RECIPE TWICE AND 
AFTER FOLLOWING IT EXACTLY MADE SOME 
CHANGES.

Options I used:
Added some salt to the meat ( a mix of
veal, pork and ground beef) and
a dash of red pepper too.

Definitely cook the meatballs in the
sauce. Soooo tender and delicious.
I cooked them for 35 minutes. Done!

Sauce Options:
Like some others I used one large can
of whole tomatoes and cut them up and
a large can of diced tomatoes.
Also, I added a few dashes of red
pepper flakes to the sauce.

Two cans of tomato paste for a richer
sauce.

Also I added one Cuban Pepper. Cut some slits into the whole pepper.
 Cooked in sauce and tossed before
serving.

Cooked in my crock pot. A great meal!

text:
AWESOME!!  Oh, this is so good!  I cannot say enough good things about this recipe.  I did use ground turkey in place of the hambuger and Ritz cracker crumbs instead of the bread crumbs...easily the BEST meatballs I have ever eaten.  For the sauce I follwed very closely..after the first 90 minutes, I did use a potato masher on the chunks of tomato (I was afraid my 5 year old won't like it with *lumps*!)  I was also a bit leary of adding the meatballs raw, but they cook up moist and just perfect in the 30 minutes of simmering.  This is WELL worth the prep time!!!

text:
I know I'm preaching to the choir here, but this was too awesome not to not leave feedback. Like others, I was a little hesitant to cook the meatballs without browning them first but I've always hated the process of browning the first because it takes constant attention and usually has to be in several batches. I don't regret not browning them one bit: they were tender and moist but still held together really well. 
That said about the delicious meatballs, the true star of the show is the sauce. It has such a fresh, bright flavor and nice chunky texture: I could eat it with a spoon like soup! AND, as a matter of fact, I've added it to soups, used it for lasagna, on homemade pizza and on top of ravioli. I'll never buy commercially prepared sauce again! I've made this at least six time since I originally made the spaghetti and meatballs two months ago. 
The ONLY change I made (and this is just personal preference) was to add a little oregano and a few flakes of red pepper for some kick. 
Thank you for sharing this great recipe!

text:
These are great meatballs! I have a big family so I tripled the recipe put fresh garlic in place of the powder, added a little onion powder to the mixture. They held their shape and was nice and firm with a little chew to them. The sauce is super easy and the longer it simmered the better it tasted. I didn't have the best pot for the job so I had to stir it alot to keep it from scortching on the bottom. We are also big mushroom eaters so I added that to the sauce didn't change the taste. My family loved it and we plan to use the few leftovers for dinner tonight and make grinders. I can't wait. Oh yeah I too was nervous about the meat not being precooked but they cooked up very well I simmered mine for 45 mins just because I had so many and they were all done. Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Long story short, I thought I had spaghetti sauce in the cupboard.  I didn't.  I had to make sauce, so I chose this recipe because I had all ingredients on hand and it looked easy enough. 

Fast forward to now.  The only reason my husband has stopped raving about this meal is that he went to bed.  He said that this ranks in the Top 5 meals I've ever made.....   He also asked me to make additional batches to put in the freezer so we always have some on-hand.  I've never gotten this kind of reaction from him before.  Who knew it was this easy?  
Anyhow, I made the recipe almost as written.  I only had crushed tomatoes, so I used those instead of whole.  Also, I did have to add about 1/3 cup of water toward the end of the final 30 minutes, but that was it.  Obviously I'll be making this again.  Thanks for a great recipe, Jeremy!

country:

text:
The only thing bad I can say about this sauce is that I am depressed that it took me this long to find it.  I have probably tried dozens of recipes for the perfect sauce over the years, and while some are better than others, overall I always just felt like something was missing.  At first I almost didn't try the sauce because it sounded so darned easy and had so few ingredients.  I am so glad I did - it is literally what I've been looking for my whole life.  I cannot comment on the meatballs because I didn't make them.  I have made the recipe as written about a half a dozen times.  The only change I make is a slight one - I add ground beef with the onions and garlic, because we like a meaty sauce.  At the end, before I serve, I remove the bayleaf and use my emulsion hand blender to blend the sauce in the pan so that it is a smooth sauce (kids hate large pieces of tomato in their sauce.  The result is literally a thing of beauty, and it clings to the pasta perfectly.  If you are not preparing to make this sauce right now, you are missing out!

text:
My first homemade spaghetti sauce was fabulous!!!  Minor substitutions:   I used one 28-oz can of crushed tomatoes and one 28-oz can of diced tomatoes seasoned with basil, garlic & oregano.   I also used only 1 tsp of salt.   After sauteeing the onion & garlic, I put everything (except the tomato paste, basil & pepper) into the crockpot and let it simmer on low for about 5-6 hours.   I added those last 3 ingredients along with 1/4 cup red wine (malbec) and my own homemade prebaked meatballs for one more hour.    SUPER!!!!   Goodbye jarred sauce!

text:
Delicious! The meatballs came out perfectly tender. The key is the fresh breadcrumbs, they soak up sauce and become "moisture blobs" in the meatballs. lol. I added more garlic to them and threw in a little salt and a small amount of red pepper flakes to avoid the bland tasting meatballs that some other reviewers mentioned. I will definitely make this again. As with all recipes that call for basil, I implore you to use fresh basil (Use 3X the amount when using fresh!), it's so much better than dry basil.

text:
After reading reviews, I gave this recipe a shot even though I, like other reviewers, was skeptical about not pre-cooking the meatballs.  Dont be!!  Fantastic Recipe.  My reason for giving 4 stars? First, I hate whole tomates, and even though I used them this time, I will definately use diced the next.  And also the Directions.  Make the Sauce first, then the meatballs.  To me, it was just bad time management to not have the sauce simmering while making the meatballs.  Great tasting recipe and I look foreward to making this again.  **Update**  I made this again with turkey, because it's always good to have a healthier option.  It was terrible.  The meatballs turned out extremely dry and tasteless.  Even the sauce tasted different.  From now on, I'll only use extra lean ground beef.

text:
These meatballs turned out so delicious - we had this dinner for three nights in a row (I used 1.5 lbs of ground beef)!  I have always made my own sauce, pretty much the same as this recipe calls for, except I always add about half a cup of ketchup and a couple tablespoons or so of worcestershire sauce (these really make a difference), as well as a splash of red wine and lots of herbs.  I baked the meatballs for about 20 min @ 350F to get some excess fat off, but finished them off in the sauce.  They were tender and delicious.  Try adding a bit of cayenne pepper if you like things a bit spicy too.

text:
This dish is phenomenal!!!....I make it regularly!!!! ??  
I doubled the recipe for my family if five. *FYI - 2 lbs of meat = about 40, 1" meatballs and did half ground beef and half Italian sausage.  I used Italian seasoned panko bread crumbs.  For the sauce I pureed Aldi organic canned diced tomatoes for a smoother sauce.  I used half the amount of sugar. I didn't have bay leaves so used oregano this time. Also added Italian seasoning.  **And yes, the raw meatballs cook perfectly in the hot sauce...they started turning brown within minutes of being added.
Oh SOOOOO yummy!!!!!!!

text:
If I could give this 100 stars, I would!  This review is mostly for the sauce:  This is hands down the best, easy spaghetti sauce I've ever made.  It's better than anything from a jar - and just as easy to use.  The batch is enormous - so you can make it and freeze half, and have it on hand for those emergency dinners when you don't know what else to make.  The first several times I made it, I followed the recipe exactly.  I now triple the onion, double the garlic and basil, and add an equal part of oregano to the basil.  Delicious and oh-so-flavorful.  The meatballs are delicious and tender but not any better than any others that I've had.  I do like that you cook them in the sauce, and it does add another flavor dimension to it.

text:
The sauce was nice - nothing earth shattering, but easy and tasty. I made it in the crockpot based on another review here, great idea! I would make this again, but I would make the meatballs about half the size next time. The recipe says to make 12, but they are really big, and as some have noted here they have kind of a bready texture from all the breadcrumbs. I think if you didn't have to cut into them but could just pop them in your mouth they would be more appealing. I would also add a little minced onion or something to them next time. But overall, nice recipe.

text:
I love this recipe and give it, along with the dry ingredients to brides for a shower gift.  I do find the recipe incredibly salty, so always cut the salt in half.  I'm sure it probably tastes better to also follow the cooking instructions, but I throw all the ingredients in the pot, bring to a boil and simmer until meatballs are cooked through (approx 30 min) saves time at the end of a long work day.  Spaghetti with meatballs just feels more special then mixing ground beef into the sauce.

I have made this recipe several times and it's a big hit! I will say I followed the directions to the "T" the first time I made this sauce so I could factually report on someone else's recipe. text:
Loved this recipe! My family raved over it tonight as they ate all up. I doubled the meatball recipe and made eight large meatballs. I also used fresh basil and parsley from the garden in the sauce. Also added about 1/4 tsp of baking soda to the sauce before putting in the meatballs. My father-in-law who is from Croatia and whose mother is from Italy taught me to do this 20 years ago when he first taught me how to make his mother's spaghetti sauce. It cuts the acidity and gives the sauce a smoother taste. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

None
text:
This sauce is great! For years I've been looking for a good spaghetti sauce. I didn't make the meatballs but added 2lbs ground chuck instead.

For the tomatoes I used 2 28 oz cans of diced tomato with garlic and olive oil because that's what I had in my pantry. Before adding the bay leaf I ran my immersion blender through the sauce to smooth it out because my husband doesn't like tomato chunks. 

We really noticed how much lighter this was than jarred sauce. It was great without all the added sugar and preservatives. It was delicious!

Next time I'll add some chopped green or red pepper and some portabella mushrooms. You could also add shredded carrots and zucchini. If your family doesn't care for added veggies, you could sautee them and puree them in a food processor to hide them. :)

I have not tried this sauce yet, but I made the meatballs and they are the best meatballs I have ever had. They are so moist and just amazingly delicious! It is the perfect amount of seasoning. They just melt in your mouth. The only thing I did different from the recipe was to brown the outside of the meatballs in a panand then tossed them into the sauce to cook the rest of the way. I wanted to keep any excess fat from going in as well...trying to eat healthier. But I must say, I will never eat another meatball again! I am trying the sauce next week, I can just imagine how delicious that will be. Thank You for posting this recipe--A true delight!!

None
text:
This is an easy, great tasting receipe and was a big hit with my wife. She always cooks her meatballs first, so this was a departure from our norm. My notes: (1) If you're in a hurry start the sauce first, then the meatballs. (2) With the meatballs cooking for 30 min. in the sauce they were really moist and nice. I modified the recepe a bit as well based on other reviews. For the meatballs I added a tsp of fennel and cooked a Johnsonville Sweet Italian Sausage, put it in the blender, and added it to 12 oz beef/4 oz ground pork. (3) As blondeprincess mentioned after the 90 min. of simmering I took the peeled whole tomato sauce and put it in the blender to puree the sauce - great idea. (4) I also added to the sauce 1/4 cup of red wine and a tsp. of italian seasoning.

text:
Awesome. I am a novice cook and I made this for my family last night. Super easy, and REALLY GOOD (I'm talking impress-the-parents good.) Only changes I made:

Sauce:
Added some red pepper flakes to sauce before simmering (we like it spicy)
Used one 28 oz. can whole tomatoes and one 28 oz. can crushed - better consistency
2 tsp. of sugar instead of 1 - it was tasting a little too tomato-ey
Added 1/2 tsp. each of sage, rosemary, and thyme (Simon and Garfunkel knew what they were talking about)

Meatballs:
These were so great. The only change I made was adding 1 tbsp. of ricotta to the mix.

Otherwise I followed the recipe as is. I would print it out and frame it if I could. Love it, love it, love it.

Happy cooking!

text:
I am different than most...I love this recipe for the sauce.  Even though this sauce is amazing, we donât like the meatballs, hence my 4 star rating.  Trust me though, the sauce really is great and since I can't cook to save my life (really I can't), I look like a chef with this one...you can't go wrong.  I pull this one out now when I want to impress people because I want people to think what a great cook I am.  Thanks! UPDATE:  I've been making/canning this for at least nine months, maybe more.  This is a HIT everywhere I go and people beg me for a jar (or 2).  People swear my sauce is absolutely the best sauce ever made.  I will admit, over time I've made a few adjustments (don't we all).  I rarely make just one batch of this at a time.  I almost always make at least 2 or 3.  And when I'm canning it I make 6.  I use A LOT more garlic.  The recipe calls for 5 cloves, but with that amount, we couldn't taste the flavor.  So I use a large bulb per 2 batches.  I know it sounds like a lot, but it really isn't (especially if you like garlic).  I used at least 1 large sweet onion per 2 batches.  I also now make it so the spices at the end are 1t basil, 1t oregano and 1/2t pepper (per batch).  I read somewhere (maybe here) that if your sauce is bitter it could be from the paste and you just need to simmer it longer. I cook mine for 90 min before adding the paste/spices and then at least 90 min if not more before serving.  HTH someone!

This was really good, I'm giving it 4 stars because I did make some modifications. Good base.   I have a big family and doubled the recipe; I used 2 28-oz cans of crushed tomatoes rather than whole; 1 15-oz can of diced tomatoes with onion and garlic; 2 15-oz cans of tomato sauce; and 1 can of tomato paste.  I was afraid that adding another can of tomato paste would make the sauce too thick once I added the meatballs.  Other than those changes and a sprinkling of Italian Seasoning, I made this recipe exactly as described.  We all loved the meatballs, and the sauce was tasty.  I also made some italian sausage in the oven to serve with the spaghetti...I bet that would be awesome thrown (precooked) into the pot in the last 15-min to 1/2 hour!

text:
I made this over a year ago and had no desire to make it again until now.  Although both times I thought it was good, next time I think I will cut down on the breadcrumbs as the meatballs were a little too dry and bready.  I will also brown the meatballs before dropping into the sauce, either in a skillet or in the oven.  The carmelization on the meatballs from browning will add flavor to the sauce (says Rachael Ray) LOL.  I think that will also cut down on grease in the sauce.  The sauce is acidic as some have said and I'm not sure how to remedy that.  Might try draining the tomatoes and adding  beef broth instead.  I look forward to making again with these changes.

text:
I (like several other reviewers) don't get home to make a fabulous meal that takes 2 hours or I would be eating at 9pm each night. So I cheated on this recipe - I made the meatballs exactly as the recipe called for. They were delicious!! Really flavorful - great texture and perfectly cooked. I didn't make the spaghetti sauce myself, instead using just Bertolli's olive oil and garlic spaghetti sauce. I simmered the meatballs in the spaghetti sauce for 30  minutes and they cooked perfectly. I also only cook with whole wheat pasta (used penne for this).  My husband loved them too! Definitely going on the repeat list. I have tried several other meatball recipes on here and I think this is the best! Thanks for sharing!

text:
This was just OK.  I think 1 cup of bread crumbs was just too much and the Parmesan not enough; overall the meatballs were bland to our taste and definitely needed salt.  Will try again with 1/2 cup bread crumbs, 1/4 cup of Parmesan, 1/2 teaspoon of garlic salt, and a bit of Cavender's Greek seasoning.  For the sauce I will use brown sugar, a heaping teaspoon of Italian seasoning, 1/2 teaspoon of fennel; just dump it all together in my slow cooker and add the meatballs about 45 minutes before we are ready to eat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm from India and love Italian food. If there is ONE recipe I'd want to take away from Allrecipes in all these years- it's this one! This recipe is delicious, easy and comforting & always has me looking forward to leftovers the next day. I cook just for myself & to reduce cooking time I either freeze some of the meatball sauce for later or I just freeze the meatballs flat in a ziploc bag to add to a new batch of sauce whenever I make it next. Leftovers can also be layered into lasagna or meatball subs. I make sure I have firm but moist meatballs by adding a little milk to the breadcrumbs. My meatballs used to crumble (rupture rather) initially but I think the issue was in the rolling-- roll them with no cracks in the hollows of your palms. (I have practice from rolling gulab jamuns!) I also use only fresh tomatoes, plumped & skinned in boiling water. The recipe is pretty flexible and I'm partial to upping the garlic sometimes (20 cloves), using lots of fresh basil if on hand, mushrooms and peppers and sometimes even half a cup of good red wine. It's a easy and forgiving recipe if you're cooking in a kitchen where you may not have all the ingredients & the main key is to let it simmer for those full 2 hours so all the flavors meld into deliciousness!

None
text:
I LOVE this recipe. I've made it a few times. It tastes great as listed without modifications but I wanted to add a couple issues.   Browning vs Not Browning It honestly works both ways; however, I felt like browning the meatballs made them more flavorful. When i didn't brown them, they were a bit bland in the sauce. My Italian boyfriend even could tell the difference. I would suggest browning for more flavor.   Bitterness: One time the sauce came out bitter. I still am not sure why. I think it might have been the dry ingredients instead of using fresh or possibly sauteing the garlic too long. I used more sugar and was able to cut the bitterness out.   Tricks/Tips:  Couple things I tried made the meatballs awesome! Seasoning the egg with salt, adding 1/4 cup Parm cheese to the meatballs, and soaking the bread crumbs in a little bit of light table cream (I'm sure milk works too).   I hope this helps some with the same questions that I originally had.

None
text:
My family is still raving about this recipe and I made for them over a month ago.  I've made this recipe and used it for eggplant and chicken parmesan, lasagna, meatball subs, and it's intended spaghetti and meatball purpose.  I made 2 modifications.  1st I only put in 2T of tomato paste rather than an entire can.  2nd I used diced tomatoes rather than whole.  The first time I made this I found that it was really acidic from the canned tomatoes, so I added 1/4t of baking soda at a time until the acidity was very mild (I think I used about 3/4t total).  Adding sugar makes the sauce sweet, but baking soda will cut the acidity without adding any sweetness.  Thank you so much for this recipe!!!

country:

text:
Okay, so basically I used this recipe as a guideline, that's why I'm only giving it 4 stars.  With my modifications it's 5 stars folks, and easier too!  Here's where it's at:  I followed the sauce recipe pretty much exactly, but when I sauted the onion and garlic, I added 2 extra cloves of garlic and 1/2 an extra onion.  After the onions are translucent and you've added the garlic, spoon about a third out and dump them into the bread/milk mixture I'm about to tell you about. I was in a time crunch so I just cranked the heat and left the lid off and the sauce thickened up just fine in about 30ish minutes.  I revamped the meatballs completely.  Before you start the sauce, tear up 2 slices of white bread and pour about 1/4 cup of milk over them.  Let them soak while you get the onions and garlic cookin'.  After you've added the onions and garlic, add 1 tsp. each oregano and basil, 1 tsp salt and a few grinds of black pepper.   Then add the 1 lb of ground beef.  Lastly, squish it all up with your hands.  Fun.  Roll them into golf ball sized balls, and after they are all done, toss them in the sauce.  Don't freak out if you can see some chunks of bread.  It's fine, really.  Hope that's not too confusing!

text:
Instead of breadcrumbs I added 1 cup oatmeal to make them lighter. I also added 1 5oz can evaporated milk to make them moist. I also browned them in some olive oil first & then removed them from the pan & started the sauce. I think its too much onion in the sauce but we aren't huge onion people so next time I will cut the onion down to 1/2 cup. I just felt like the sauce was all onion. I also added oregano & some garlic salt to the sauce. I simmered all the sauce ingredients for 45 min. because I was short on time & then added the meatballs & cooked for 30 min. I think it helped to brown the meatballs so they weren't so raw going into the sauce. Overall, this is a really easy, yummy recipe & I will definatley be making it again!

text:
This was my first time making my own red sauce and meatballs. I have to say that it was simple, with delicious results. I was very proud to serve the finished product. I don't know why people are making a fuss about the sugar. 1 teaspoon of sugar didn't make much of a difference in the taste. Consider that there is much more of all the other seasonings. I recommend trying the recipe the way it's presented here. It's definitley worth the risk.
There are only two of us, so there was quite a  bit left over, instead of cutting down on the recipe, we used the leftovers for meatball sandwiches! Best meatball sandwiches I have ever had!

text:
I would have given this recipe more stars if the recipe had included oregano from the beginning.  It's true what some of the other reviewers have said about the sauce-it is very tomato-ish, without the oregano it almost tastes like plain tomato sauce. Soooo, try adding 2- 3 teaspoons oregano (I also added 1 tbsp cilantro).  This fixed it for me.  Much better!

As for the rest of the recipe - it's really good!

text:
This is a basic recipe and very blah.  The meatballs didn't really have any flavor, on the first bite, it tasted like biting into a round hamburger ball.  Def need ALOT more spices/herbs. As for the sauce, using whole tomatoes makes the sauce very thick and even after simmering for 90 mins, some of the tomatoes still didn't crush/dissolve, so next time save the trouble of blending and buy crush tomatoes instead.  Also the sauce was very acidic.  Using 1 teaspoon of sugar for 2 (28oz) cans of tomatoes and a can of tomato paste is not enough!!!  I cut the acidity by adding atleast 3 tablespoons of sugar and maybe 2-3 tablespoons of butter. Next time I will add more herbs to both the meatballs and sauce.

text:
This recipe was an absolute hit with my whole family..something that doesn't happen very often!!  The first time I made it, one of my sons ate 5 of the meatballs before I even served dinner.  Therefore, I now double the meatball part of the recipe. The only change was that I added 1 1/2 cups of breadcrumbs, instead of 2 cups, to the 2 pounds of ground sirloin.  I use petite diced tomatoes and double the amount of chopped onions.  One time I sauteed sliced mushrooms with the onions and the sauce was also fabulous.  Today, I used a hand blender to partially puree the sauce.  I add on an extra 15 minutes of cooking time for the meatballs.  This is such a great recipe, you can "tweak" it any way you like and it still comes out GREAT!!  Thanks so much!! This is definitely a keeper!!  Better than our favorite Italian restaurant!!

Beat recipe on this site. Iâve made it so many times I just absolutely love it over jar sauce. It is time consuming in a sense so I do make a double batch to help for future use. I freeze the rest in quart size bags. I do make the meatballs fresh each time. Iâve done a few versions of this after following the recipe the first time. This is what I do. Extra garlic. Half crushed tomatoes half diced tomatoes. One can of tomato paste per double batch. Add salt at the end so I can add more if needed. Use what I need for dinner and just cool off and freeze remainder in quart size bags. Iâm only a family of 2 adults and a 5 year old so I have plenty of sauce for future uses. We eat either spaghetti and meatballs, eggplant Parmesan, chicken Parmesan, or lasagna every week or 2, so saving 2 hours each time is worth it. I canât say enough about how good this recipe is.

text:
This was delicious! I actually make my sauce and meatballs almost identical to this recipe except I always bake the meatballs first, then add them to the sauce. I made this recipe exactly as written (which is how I believe recipes should be reviewed. If you change it then you are reviewing your recipe). I left the meatballs simmering in the sauce a little longer just because I wasn't ready to eat. I'm sure they would have been ready in the time suggested in the recipe. The meatballs absorbed the flavors of the sauce. They are much better this way. No need to brown or precook. This is my go to recipe from now on!

This was REALLY GOOD!  I adjusted a bit using one 28 ounce can of tomato sauce and one 28 ounce can of whole tomatoes, and also used 1 tablespoon of Italian seasoning in the meatballs (vs parsley). I put Italian seasoning in the sauce too. I put in the crock pot on high for a few hours and then turned to low.  I did feel like the whole tomatoes were still too chunky so I did puree them in my Ninja blender.  This was SO DELICIOUS! Very easy and definitely go-to spaghetti and meatballs recipe for the future!

This is my second review for this recipe and once again, I give it 5 stars.  I'm adding another review today because I read through a ton of reviews today before starting and was surprised by a few.  I cannot believe the people that said that this dish is bland, be it the meatballs or the sauce.  This dish is so flavorful!  And I love, love, love the way my house smells while its cooking!  Those that think it's bland or just tastes like tomatoes are obviously doing something wrong or their ingredients are poor quality.  It's also possible that they're not cooking for the full amount of time.  Today, I made this dish exactly as the recipe is written, no changes AT ALL. It is time consuming but worth every minute.  My husband and both of my kids, 14 and 7 say that this is the best spaghetti and meatballs that they have ever had.

text:
We loved this, we have sophisticated pallets and are not sure why there were so many saying it needed so many changes. I simmered meatballs in the sauce, I only changed two things using fresh parsley not dried and half beef half ground pork.(tip to others about dry meatballs the recipe calls for fresh not dry bread crumbs so just cut into small pieces or thru a mini chopper, if you are using dry you must soak about half the amount in milk with fat). On the sauce I added 1/2 tsp crushed red pepper because we like heat and I used San Marzano tomatoes. Perfect!

country:
None
text:
THE BEST SAUCE I'VE EVER MADE! This is my 1st time leaving a review (although I've been on this site for many years- I HAD to review this one!)Don't let the simplicity of this recipe fool you- it's wonderful! I used ground turkey (all I had on hand at the time) so I omitted the breadcrumbs and upped the Parmesan cheese to 2Tbsp. Otherwise I followed the recipe exactly as written. No need to precook the meatballs- cooking them inside the sauce is what I believe makes this sauce so delicious. I will Never use another recipe- and that says a lot because I'm always switching things up here and there-but don't mess with perfection once you find it! Thank you Jeremy!
Update: I forgot to add that before I put my meatballs into the sauce to cook for the final 30 minutes I pull out the bay leaves and then  I drop an immersion blender into the pot and blend it into a completely smooth consistency- it's a personal preference- my family likes a smooth sauce and it blends all the flavors together so nicely.

text:
I found this recipe to be very tasty.  I omitted the salt and used "no salt added" tomatoes for a healthier sauce. You can't tell that the salt is missing.  I also used fresh parsley instead of dried, I think it has better flavor, and added some Pecorino Romano and Parmesan about a Tablespoon or so of each. Since I had already made meatballs and had them frozen, I just added them to the sauce to defrost and heat up. This is now my favorite sauce, when I make it I make enough to freeze for later and it tastes even better after it has been frozen.
This one is a keeper! Even my husband loves it.

text:
I looooove this meatball recipe!  I followed the meatball recipe exactly as it was written.  Because I wanted larger meatballs, I changed the serving from 6 servings to 9 servings so that I can use 3 pounds of beef.  I used a 1/4 measuring cup to measure out my meat portions so that they could cook uniformly--which brought it to 11 giant balls.  For the sauce, I used a ready-made sauce due to time and added some extra ingredients to make it my own.  Overall, the meatballs came our tender and flavorful.  This will be my go-to recipe for meatballs from now on!

text:
Very good with some slight alterations.  Pre-cooked the meatballs for 15 min at 425 to seal in flavor and brown the outsides.  For extra gooeyness, added 1/4 c. shredded mozzarella cheese to meatballs and used refrigerated garlic.  For sauce, sauteed garlic (refrigerated) and 1.5 small onions in 2 T. olive oil.  Added 2 large cans of crushed tomatoes, 2 cans tomato paste (we like really thick sauce!) and 2 bay leaves.  Let simmer for 90 minutes total at low heat.  YUMMY!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My four star rating is based on the accuracy of the recipe. Follow the instructions and it'll turn out pretty good. One thing I would say is that the meatballs were horribly bland. To fix it simply, add 1 tsp of salt to the meatball mixture. To fix it the best, use another meatball recipe. I've made a few tomato sauce based recipes, and one tip I can give is when using whole canned tomatoes, pulse them in the blender to smooth them out before putting them into the sauce, or put them through a food sieve. Without this step, you'll find huge chunks of tomato in your sauce which make it difficult and unpleasant to eat.
 Also, be sure to remove the bay leaves before serving, these become papery or leathery when cooked, and are unpleasant to eat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really loved this sauce!! It had SO much flavor!  I'll be honest though, I wasn't overly impressed with the meatballs but that is just my opinion. I did a few things differently, which could have caused them to taste different (like forgetting the Parmesan cheese lol...). For one I browned the meatballs in a skillet, then deglazed it with a little brandy and put that into the sauce. In addition, rather than using two 28 oz cans of whole tomatoes I used a 28 oz can of crushed tomatoes, a 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes (with garlic, basil, and oregano), and a 15 oz can of tomato sauce. I also added a bit more seasoning than it called for, as well as oregano, parsley, and onion and garlic powders. 
For the meatballs, I was planning to add half pork, half ground beef but they were out of pork at the store. I ended up cutting open a bratwurst and putting that in, but it didn't make much of a difference. Maybe I'd add some Italian sausage or something next time. I want to close this review by saying, this sauce is awesome!!! I would definitely make it again!

text:
I absolutely love this recipe! Like others, I was concerned the meatballs would not cook through because the recipe did not call for browning them first, but they were perfect.  I make batches of the sauce often and freeze it.  It's perfect to use over spaghetti, lasagna and even as pizza sauce (yummy!). I also blended the 2 cans of crushed tomatoes to get rid of any large chunks because I have some picky eaters in my household.

I would give this a 3.5. I made modifications and added extra flavoring (more garlic, more seasonings in the sauce, more parm. cheese in the meatballs) but it still fell a little flat.  The meatballs really lacked flavor, but the sauce was good. I used 1.5 tablespoons of sugar and it was still too acidic tasting, so I might do 2 tablespoons next time. text:
Easy and DELICIOUS! It was my first time to make homemade sauce and meatballs (because my boyfriend refuses to use store bought sauce) and I couldn't be happier with the result!
I made just a few slight modifications to the original recipe: I used half a pound of hamburger and half a pound of Italian sausage for the meatballs, I added about half a teaspoon of oregano to the meatball mixture, and I browned the meatballs in a skillet before putting them in the sauce (I prefer that texture, plus I wanted to drain the grease/fat off also).
I started preparing at 11:30am, and once it was done I just let it simmer for hours. Excellent recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We LOVED this recipe. Served it to company and they asked for the recipe. Both the meatballs and the sauce were excellent. I made only the slightest variations; I made a triple batch and used 2 pounds of lean (93 percent) ground beef and 1 pound of ground pork.  Also, I didn't have bread for fresh crumbs, so I just used seasoned panko. I did cut the bread crumbs in half since I was serving some diabetics who are carb conscious, and the meatballs were still outstanding. Also, I made mine in the crockpot so I didn't saute the garlic and onion ahead of time - I added it fresh in the crockpot and bypassed the olive oil and the sauce was perfect.  For Newbie - it's two 28-ounce cans, for a total of 56 ounces.

What can I say that hasn't already been said by over 1,000 reviews!  I've made this many, many times after finding it on this site.  A few changes that I've made: add milk to the meatball mixture, it'll make them more flavorful and lots of fresh basil.  I try to make this the night before so the flavors have time to "set."  Use any extra meatballs with a little sauce for meatball subs too!

country:
None
text:
Fantastic. This was my first spaghetti sauce. I tweaked a bit because it wasn't sweet enough for me, plus I wanted a little extra spice. I used 3/4 tsp Italian seasoning and 1/4 tsp basil. I also added a pinch of crushed red pepper, 1/2 tsp sugar, and half a can of tomato soup. I pureed the tomatoes as well, for a smoother sauce. I simmered for about 3 hours on low. I found the sauce to be a bit too rich and chunky so I added 1/4 cup water and pureed in the blender. The meatballs were good but I had to add another egg and leave out some of the bread crumbs.

text:
Anybody who doesn't like this recipe obviously did not do it right! I made a few small changes, such as using a combination of diced and stewed tomatoes, added some italian seasoning to the sauce, used a combination of ground beef and ground turkey, soaked italian bread crumbs in milk for the meatballs instead of using fresh bread crumbs, and baked the meatballs in the oven as I didn't want it to be greasy (who can afford lean ground beef these days), but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. It turned out fantastic and my family absolutely devoured it. I made a double batch but barely had enough leftover for meatball subs the next day. We will never go back to the bottled sauce again!

text:
I would give this recipe 10 stars if I could.  This recipe tastes like an authentic Italian restaurant meal.  I made this for the first time and my husband cannot stop raving about this.  The only changes I made was that I used a combination of beef, pork and veal and added 1 1/2 eggs for moister meatballs.  I am sodium restricted and used 4 cans (14.5 oz) of petite cuts no salt added and added 2 bay leaves.   I baked the meatballs for 10 minutes at 350 and turned them over and baked for another 10 minutes and then added them to the sauce.  They were even better the next day I found it hard not to have them for breakfast.  Thank you Jeremy for making my first time making meatballs and sauce a total hit with my family.  This is a keeper and is top of the list.

text:
We used a whole lg. onion and still didn't that much oil -- a couple of tbsps is plenty.  Used a combo of whole peeled, italian stewed and diced tomatoes for more of a medium texture. Needed more sugar to cut the acidity and more basil PLUS oregano.  Mushrooms would be a good addn., as would a little bellpepper.  If you don't have fresh breadcrumbs, be sure to use less than the full cup called for, or your meatballs will be dry/crumbly.  Added a little italian seasoning to the meatballs too.  All in all -- good as written, but you may need a few tweaks on the seasonings to get it just right for you.

text:
Wow! So flavorful. I have always made my own spaghetti sauce but this combination just clicked. Like others, I was skeptical of cooking my meatballs right in the sauce. I kept thinking of all that grease released from the beef, floating around in the sauce. To ease my mind a bit I used ground sirloin which is leaner than ground round or chuck. I've learned my lesson about changing up a recipe before I have even tried it. I now make new recipes the way they were intended to be made, unless it's an ingredient I really don't like. Having said that, I did make one tiny change that didn't affect the flavor. I added about 1/3 of a cup of milk to the meatballs. Next time I will add a few more spices and garlic to the meatballs, but this is great as is. Thank you Jeremy.

Wonderful recipe! I did change a lot, per reviewerâs recommendations and necessity. For the sauce- Used 1 (28 oz) can of crushed tomatoes with Italian style seasoning, 1 (28 oz) can of tomato puree, added Â¼ bunch parsley sprigs and scooped them out, added italian seasoning, left out the bay leaf, and added a bit of red wine. For the meatballs- added Italian seasoning, used Unikass Robusto cheese from Whole Foods (all I had at hand) instead of parm (and I doubled the amount), and used ritz crackers instead of the bread crumbs. I also used hot sausage and ground beef. Lots of changes, but delicious!

This is delightfull. Lick bowl worthy. I am in love.  I did not have bread crumbs (I usually crush stale bread with a rolling pin) so I toasted bread and crumbled it.  To the meat balls I added cyanne pepper and hot sauce because i like it spicy. I also made the meatballs smaller, a bit smaller then a gold ball. Because they were smaller i added them in the last (about) 22 minutes instead of 30.   To the sauce I added dried basil and oregano.   I served over thin whole wheat spaghetti.  All so amazing and easy. Left overs are very good too.

text:
I made this for dinner this evening and it turned out FANTASTIC!!!!  I have been looking for a spaghetti sauce and meatball recipe for my keeper collection and I have found it.  I modified the recipe a bit.  I used 2 cans of tomato sauce and one can of diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes and tomato paste.  I also didn't have 90 minutes to simmer the sauce and it still tasted great after only 30 minutes.  For the meatballs, Instead of cooking them in the sauce, I baked them on a cookie sheet, covered with foil, at 400 degrees for 20 minutes.  I got approximately 20 out of the recipe.  Can't wait for leftovers for lunch!!!  YUMMY!

country:

text:
Fabulous!  I will admit a change or two...  First of all for the sauce, I used 3 cloves of garlic and will next time use more like 1 1/2...  next, I changed the tomatoes around some.  I used a 28 oz can of Tomatoes (ended up chopping them up - could've used diced) and a 28 oz can of tomato sauce - I left out the sugar and bay leaf totally (too sweet for me).  For the meatballs, I used 1 1/2 #'s of a meatloaf mix of ground beef, ground veal and ground pork.  I used Ritz crackers (3/4 cup) instead of bread crumbs  and about 1/3 pkg of Lipton Onion Soup Mix ~ no garlic powder needed.   I cooked the sauce at 2 hours, then added the meatballs and 6 oz can of tomato paste, 12 oz tomato sauce and black pepper.  The meatballs cooked about another 1 1/2 hours or a little more...  Served over the little pasta 'nests', spinach w/cucumber and tomato salad and fresh Italian bread.  Served with a Sterling 2002 Merlot... absolutely magnificant!!!  Spectcular Dinner...  with a simple modification to this recipe... can't wait to taste the leftovers...  OMG - the best I've ever made

text:
This was an amazing sauce! It is very flexible and can be added to or altered to fit individual tastes but the basic recipe is still 5-star. I used whole tomatoes but then crushed them with a potato masher. I added some fresh zucchini, carrots, and mushrooms with everything, simmered for about 45 minutes, then added the meatballs and simmered for another 30 minutes. I did puree some of the sauce to thicken the consistency (the zucchini made it a little watery) and served with parmesan and some fresh basil. Delicious!

This recipe turned out very well. I took another user's comment to add 1/2 cup of milk, water or sauce to the meatballs when using ground turkey, otherwise the meatballs will be too dry. text:
This was a super easy and delicious recipe. Two recommendations: 1. Next time I will use WAY less salt, it was very salty and I ended up having to put some water in the sauce near the end of the cooking process (this also helped because alot of the sauce evaporated and I did not overcook). 2. I put alot of extra seasoning in to spice it up a little - a pinch more garlic, some cayenne pepper, extra black pepper and some dried cilantro. I really think this improved it dramatically. Overall a great recipe to impress friends with who are wanting a good home cooked meal.

userID:

Display Name:
Alicia Wingard
isPro:

73

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4414061.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like some others I was hesitant to put raw meat in my sauce...but it turned out fantastic. I made a few changes based on some of the other reviews. I used 2 slices of bread that were soaked in milk then blended them. Sounds weird if you have not made meatballs before but trust me it makes all the difference! I also added a packet of Lawry's seasoning for spaghetti to the sauce. When my boyfriend came home after the sauce had been cooking he said it smelt just like an Italian restaurant. I had to remove the meatballs and add another can of tomato paste (i was afraid of messing up the balls by stirring in the paste) This is time consuming but WELL WORTH IT! Next time I will do the meatballs the night before put the sauce in the crock pot and let it simmer ALL DAY so we can have a wonderful meal on a week night! Do add soggy milk bread to your meatballs, it adds moisture and gives an amazing texture!

I followed the recipe up to and including the onions and garlic and then for the sauce I used a jar of marinara, a can of tomato sauce and a can of diced tomatoes.  I also added 2 tblsp of italian seasoning then added the meatballs and simmered for about 45 minutes.  This was very flavorful and my husband loved it.  I was put off by adding the raw meatballs to the sauce but its so good so I will be doing that from now on.  Next time I will do it the long way....on a weekend!

text:
I'm rating the meatballs only, as I did not make the sauce.  They were ok.  They needed a LOT more seasonings.  I had to add 1 chopped onion, 2 cloves chopped garlic, bread crumbs out of crackers, more parm cheese, seasoned salt, meat seasoning, italian seasonings...  This was a good base recipe, but for my tastes, needed tweaking.  Update:  I used my leftover meatballs to make subs last night.  Reheated the meatballs while toasting some hoagie rolls that I buttered and put some garlic powder on.  Then I hollowed out slightly, cut the meatballs in half and loaded up the sandwiches.  I topped with lots of mozzarella cheese and threw back in the oven until melted and bubbly.  Very very very good use of leftovers!

text:
Outstanding! I love spaghetti but since my favorite sauce was discontinued, I needed a new one (and I'm picky). This is it! It's delicious even without the meatballs (although I made it with.) 
A time saving tip...
I got the sauce started to thepoint where it needed to "simmer for 90 minutes" then made the meatballs and put them into a 9x13 baking pan and baked them for 25 mins at 350 degrees, turning them once. By the time they were done, I blended 3 cups of the sauce in a blender and added it back to the pot. I just added the meatballs in and they were wonderful! Plenty of compliments without the 2+ hours. Delicious!! Thank you!!

None

None
text:
I loved this recipe. I wasn't sure about adding the raw meatballs since I'd always either pan fried or baked mine, but these came out perfect without a bit of grease. Just be careful when you first add them--fold them into the sauce, don't stir very hard or they will break up. I used the fresh bread crumbs and I did take one reviewer's advice and added a half cup of liquid (I used tomato sauce) and the meatballs were perfect. I used crushed tomatoes instead of whole so the sauce only had to cook for about 45 minutes before adding the meat. I also added about half a cup of parmesan cheese and 1/4 cup of red wine to the sauce just before adding the meatballs. It did take a bit longer for the meatballs to cook, but that could be because I used a blend of ground beef, ground pork and fresh Italian sausage. (about a third pound of each). I was actually just looking for a good home made sauce, and the meatballs were a pleasant bonus. This will be my standard sauce from now on.

text:
If you are not using lean beef or pork in the meatballs, it is wise to brown the meatballs to render some of the fat from them that can be a considerable amount that is hard to extract from a thick sauce. 
Concerning Parmesan Cheese...Parmesan is the French trans for Parmigiano and the trade name is protected in the European Union, PDO (protected designation of origin) but not other countries where there are poor imitations of the Parmigiani-Reggiano called Parmesan

text:
This was very good.  My husband and kids really liked it.  It took awhile because of the cooking time, but was easy and worth the wait.  I did have to make a few changes.  I added more garlic (because we love it) than called for and did not use a bay leaf because I didn't have one.  I substituted with a small amount of oregano and basil (just a pinch of each, not measured).  I also used diced tomatoes and 2 cans of tomato sauce because I did not have the whole peeled tomatoes or tomato paste.  I did only simmer the sauce for an hour before adding the meatballs because we were all hungry and didn't want to wait an hour and a half.  The only change I would make next time would be to use 1 tsp salt instead of 2 tsp because it was a little salty.

text:
I like using a mixture of equal parts of ground pork and ground sirloin. The pork increases the flavor incredibly. Then brown the meatballs in very hot olive oil on all sides before putting them in the simmering sauce for the last 2-3 hours. As for the sauce, omit the 1 tsp sugar and add 1-2 cups of a good port wine. That will give you all the sweetness you want. (A tip from my great great grandmother's Sicilian recipe.)

text:
Followed recipe except for 2 small changes - In the meatballs, I added 1/2 tsp. salt and used saltine crackers in place of bread crumbs.  

This is a good recipe.  We usually prefer a thicker sauce, but I will make this again when we're in the mood for something a little different.  

Save yourself some time - the meatballs do not need to be browned before adding!

text:
excellent recipe!  this is the first time my husband wants to bring a batch for his parents to try!
i made some modifications based on previous reviews, and also because i have celiac disease and need my meals to be gluten free.

meatballs:
added 1/4 tsp basil, oregano, rosemary, thyme and onion powder; used fresh garlic and fresh onions; used gluten free bread that i blended to make 1 cup of crumbs; added 1/2 c milk; doubled parmesan.
-still needed some flavor.  however, since the sauce is sooo flavorful, it was a good balance so i wouldn't change anything.

sauce:
added 1 tsp basil, 2 1/2 tsp oregano

the meatballs cooked through after 30 minutes and i did not bake them beforehand.  

really great recipe!

text:
My first review set!

Excellent; I comined this delicious sounding recipe with Anne Enyons "Spaghetti Sauce with Meatballs" since the recipes sounded almost identical.  The difference is where I added the extra items from Annes recipe-- like celery (1stalk diced), 1 bell pepper (diced), onion, garlic clove & salt/pepper (in meatballs).

The only things I changed are: 
(1) an extra can of diced tomatoes-- it looked like too little sauce for all the xtra meatballs I accidentally made; (2) used 1 clove garlic and 1 chopped onion in the meatballs as Anne's recipe notes; (3) I used more sugar (just a little over 1/2 tsp sugar), and more salt to the sauce 2tsp; (4) I added xtra stuff to the sauce at the "sautee" stage: 1/2 jalepeno pepper diced, whole small red pepper diced, small can of sliced mushrooms, and the celery/bell pepper noted above; (5) I omitted the milk in the meatballs b/c it sounded weird; but may try it next time.

Overall, excellent recipe! Also, fairly easy to make.  

(Note, this is my first time making spaghetti from scratch since a junior in late 90's).

text:
Yummy, Yummy, Yummy!!! I wasn't sure it would taste good with so little ingredients in the sauce, but it was AMAZING!  I ended up sauteeing the garlic and onion and putting the rest of the recipe with the sautee in my crockpot.  I set it on high for 3 hours and in the last 1.5 hours I added the basil and tomato paste.  We don't like super chunky sauce, so I took the big chunks of tomatoes and put them in my blender.  Definitely added milk to the meatballs and baked them before putting them in the sauce.  Used fresh pasta and viola!  it was delish!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I'm not a big spaghetti fan, but I find myself craving it after having made this recipe a couple times now.  The taste is fresh, the sauce is thick, and the meatballs are just perfect.  My only change was to use two cans of crushed tomatos because my daughter doesn't like a chunkier sauce.  With crushed tomatoes it comes out thick and hearty.  Meatballs need no prior cooking or browning, just plunk them in the sauce and they cook to perfection.  This is now a once a week family favorite!

text:
Delicious! As recommended I used 3/4 c. breadcrumbs and also added 1/4 c. tomato juice and 1/4 c. milk to the meatballs. To the suace I added 1 c. water and used petite diced tomatoes. The only reason it gets 4 stars instead of 5 is because of my own fear in the cooking time of the meatballs.  There is no way they could be done in 30 min. cooking in the sauce alone. I baked them for 45 min. at 325 degrees then added to the sauce for the time stated and was still uneasy about them being done. Made 18 meatballs.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took the idea of this recipe and tweaked it to my liking. I used 1 lb of 95% ground beef, 1/2 lb of italian pork sausage, 3 eggs, 3/4 C plain bread crumbs, 6 cloves of garlic finely chopped, a TON of italian seasoning and garlic powder, salt&pepper for the meatballs.  For sauce, I used 2 cans of diced tomatoes and 2 cans of tomato paste (along with 2 tomato-paste-cans of water).  I sauteed the meatballs in a deep skillet w/ extra virgin olive oil.  Then added more garlic and onions.    Then diced tomatoes/paste.  I seasoned w/ more italian seasoning, dried basil, garlic powder, little bit of sugar, salt&pepper. If you don't like chunky sauce, use crushed tomatoes instead. I let it simmer for about 2.5 hours.  It was a huge hit with everyone!

Only 4 stars because of some *small* changes I made. Added an extra egg to the meatballs, they seemed just a touch too dry. Added 
1 tbsp. Italian seasoning to the sauce and used Pomi brand strained tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes...my family does not like tomato chunks in their sauce. Pomi tomatoes have a nice  fresh taste to them and the sauce came out tasting fresh, with the herb taste shining through. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
We tried this recipe in a pinch because it looked quick and easy and the recipe rating inspired some confidence.  Unfortunately, its not like mom's.  If you're used to homemade sauce (as opposed to Ragu or Prego), you'll probably be disappointed.  Also, I highly recommend a traditional mix of ground beef, veal and pork to anybody serious about making their own meatballs.  Using only ground beef will leave you with dry meatballs, as evidenced by this recipe.

text:
First time ever making spaghetti and meatballs, it turned out great but I had to leave the meatballs on low to simmer for almost 2 hours before they cooked...did others actually find that their meatballs were cooked after 30 mins?!? So here are the changes I made that would render the recipe 5 stars in my opinion, many of which I got from the lovely folk who left reviews here:
-I used fresh herbs instead of dry. On their YouTube  video they said to use a ratio of 1:3 dry herbs to fresh herbs conversion so I used 3x fresh herbs (I.e. 3 tablespoons fresh parsley etc)
-I let the meatballs simmer for 1 hour and 45 mins
-I added a teaspoon of oregano to the sauce 
-added a clove of fresh garlic in addition to the powdered garlic for the meatballs. Next time Iâll likely add 2-3 cloves.

text:
This was awesome spaghetti and meatballs!! I was a little nervous trying it out for the first time for our Christmas dinner. Did not precook the meatballs, but prepared just as the recipe stated and they were perfect--flavorful and moist. I doubled the recipe for 6 adults and 2 grandchildren...all of the meatballs were eaten (24) and there was enough sauce left over for us 2 to have the next day. A breadcrumb tip I learned from the lady at our store's deli...put 2 slices at a time of fresh bread in a blender to create excellent bread crumbs (4 pieces total, since I doubled recipe). She actually said to toast the bread first, but I didn't and it turned out great. I did have to shake the blender a little to get the pieces to fall and blend. Definitely plan to make this again!

text:
Great, I find that this recipe is a good base. You always have to taste your sauce! Don't think that it's going to taste exactly the way you like it, because your tastebuds are your own. I added an extra tbsp of dried basil to the sauce, garlic powder, dried parsley and onion powder. I also added about a 1/2 tbsp of sea salt to the sauce as well and 1/4 tbsp sea salt to the meatballs. I read the reviews beforehand to make sure that I had this recipe to par! I never made spaghetti sauce from scratch before and this was fantastic! Definitely won't be purchasing those spaghetti sauce jars anymore because the ingredients for this was about the same price. I didn't sautÃ© the meatballs beforehand, but I did put the meatballs in the sauce for 45 minutes instead of the 30 minutes presented in the recipe. They weren't dry at all! They tasted moist and smelled wonderful when I was rolling them up! 

Thank you for posting this recipe! We loved it!

This recipe was simple to make and absolutely delicious! I did as another reviewer had suggested by using a half pound ground beef and a half pound ground Italian sausage. I also used 28 oz diced tomatoes and 28 oz whole peeled tomatoes for the sauce. Everything else I left as is and couldn't have been happier with the results.

text:
Next time I plan on adding more garlic and sugar. The sugar will help cut out the acidic/tart taste of the tomato. Also I think adding dried oregano and Thyme is essential! These herbs really helped with the flavor. I, like another reviewer, opted for 2 cans of crushed tomato to replace one can of the whole tomatoes, but next time I think I'll opt out of the whole tomatoes can completely. I like my sauce a bit more thick and consistent. Lastly, I will add in a pound of Italian sausage cooked and crumbled to the sauce. This WAS my first time making homemade sauce and it really helped me figure out what I'm looking for, but all in all was easy with a great flavor. I just need a bit more.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed the recipe, but added some fresh Italian parsley to the meatballs, a healthy tablespoon of Italian seasoning to the sauce. Was worried it would be too bland, and am glad I added the extra seasoning.  Braising the meatballs in the sauce was initially a weird idea to me, but it worked well.  Not spongey, and medium brown!  However, I still think I prefer the texture achieved via the traditional method of separately browning them first.  The only reason I am not giving this five stars is the addition of the tomato paste at the end.  I should have trusted my instinct and pre-cooked the sauce in a bit of oil to get rid of that canned taste.  I followed the recipe and just dumped it in...the tomato paste flavor never really went away, even after more than 30 minutes of simmering.  I added some balsamic vinegar to mask it a bit, but hubby still noticed the paste first thing.  So, with a few tweaks, this is a keeper!

text:
This sauce was amazing. I followed the instructions as written, but used San Marzano tomatoes in the can. They cost a little more, but have amazing taste. After 9- minutes, I used am immersion blender to blend the sauce, and then added the meatballs. I used the meatballs and sauce to make meatball sandwiches for dinner, with salad and fruit. It got rave reviews from the kids and hubby. This will be in our regular rotation of meals. Next time I plan to double the recipe and freeze the sauce in containers for a quick weeknight dinner. Thanks for sharing!

userID:
7868374
Display Name:
The Sporadic Cook
isPro:

followersCount:
14

28
favoritesCount:
102
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/801507.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is a good recipe for sauce and meatballs. I used dried Italian bread crumbs for the meatballs instead of regular bread. To adjust for the lack of moisture, I added about a 1/4 cup of 2% milk. I cut the parsley in half since the Italian bread crumbs had some already in it. I also added in a few shakes of onion powder, garlic salt, and upped the parm a little with some freshly grated. I really mashed the meatball mixture together to make sure the ground beef was mixed well with the other ingredients. I refrigerated the raw meatballs until it was time to add them to the sauce. Cooked the meatballs in the sauce on low for about an hour.

text:
Great starter recipe .  I made the following changes:  with meatballs - increased Parmesan cheese to 1/4 cup....used Italian bread crumbs .....added trinity seasoning to meat(includes garlic onion bell pepper and celery) used zatarans  creole seasoning instead of just pepper....added no salt Italian seasoning....half ground meat and half sweet Italian sausage.  With sauce- again trinity seasoning instead of just onion....28 oz crushed tomato....28 oz diced tomato...add can of Italian seasoned tomato sauce to final batch..added zatarans seasoning and Italian seasoning instead of just pepper...and increased sugar to 3 tsp.  Well seasoned and very tasty.  Absolutely love it!

text:
I am having trouble rating the recipe, because as is I found the sauce to be really good, but the meatballs were flavourless and dry. For sauce I would rate 4/5 but for the meatballs I would rate it 2/5. 
I made modifications to the sauce following some advice from thedailygourmet review as well as well as some of my own modifications. The sauce went from good to amazing.


For the meatballs I used the existing recipe as a base but added a lot to it


For sauce - 
Used 2 28oz cans of diced Italian seasoned tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes. 
Added 1 tsp of italian seasoning, 1 tsp basil, 1 tsp garlic powder
Reduced salt to 1 1/3tsp of salt as I found 2 tsp way too salty (and I love salt).
I also found the original recipe too runny, so I used two cans of tomato paste. Next time I might try using tomato sauce
I also used immersion blender to purÃ©e the sauce


For Meatballs-
Used 1/2 lb lean ground beef and 1/2 lb lean ground pork
Used italian seasoned breadcrumbs.
Added 2 cloves of minced garlic
Added 1 tsp of marjoram
Increased parmesan cheese to 1 tablespoon
Added 1 tsp of salt
Increased black pepper to 1/2 tsp
Added 1/2 cup of milk. 
Next time I think I will reduce the amount of breadcrumbs to 1/2 cup as I think it is too much and then reduce the amount of milk to 1/4 cup
Browned meatballs in frying pan before adding to sauce. (Although this is a personal choice, it's the way I grew up with)
I found these meatballs having way more flavour and nice and juicy

country:

text:
This was a very good recipe.  I made only a couple of alterations.  I added a splash or red wine just because I don't think it is red sauce without a little red wine.  Instead of dried basil, I added Italian spice which is a blend of basil, thyme, etc.  I am not sure why a reviewer felt this recipe was overly sweet.  In fact I like my sauce a little sweeter than what this recipe called for.  The meatballs were very good.  They reminded me of the ones made by many of the Italian cooks in my hometown.  I think they always put them directly into the sauce and never browned them first.  I will definitely use this recipe again.  12/8/14  I just made this sauce again.  I used fresh herbs instead of my usual Italian blend.  I used about 2 tsp fresh oregano and 3Tbsp of fresh basil.  This really kicked up the brightness of the sauce.
