text:
A few slight changes. I used about 1-1/2 pounds of meat; a half cup of seasoned bread crumbs and half cup of wheat bran (no noticeable texture difference). I forgot the Parm cheese in the balls, but no biggie. I just added it to the finished dish. I also baked the balls 30 minutes at 350, then slid them into the sauce, which I already had underway. I happened to have a half-finished bottle of red wine (!), so I added a cup to the sauce. After cooking down for the recommended time, the sauce was VERY thick, so I added a little more wine! And a small can of tomato sauce. ;-) My dad, who is a gravy fiend, LOVED it. Easy, quick and delicious - my three favorite ingredients!

Been using this as the base of my sauce for at least 5 years.  These are the things I've changed over the years.  I use one half teaspoon of fennel, two bay leaves instead of one, add a mushrooms and green pepper to onions when I sautÃ© them, and I use the meatball nirvana recipe from this site.  If sauce looks too thick I use one half cup dry red wine.  The recipe is good as is, but with these changes it is craveable.

text:
My 4 star rating is based on way too much gravy for just 1 lb of meatballs, and the sauce needed a little extra flavor.   I actually made 3 lbs of meatballs (1 lb. beef and 2 lbs  turkey).  I kept the proportions the same, but did add a 24 oz jar of my favorite jarred wine flavored spaghetti sauce.  Even with 3 lbs of meat there was sauce left over when the meatballs were all gone, and I was surprised at how good the meatballs turned out -- and so easy to make -- just scooped the meat with  an ice cream scooper, and dropped them in the hot sauce after rolling into balls.  Will make again.

Display Name:
Casie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6351704.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FINALLY a recipe that tells you to cook the meatballs in the sauce! I used to frown at any recipe that tells you to brown the meatballs in a skillet or in the oven. WRONG, you lose all that beefy flavor when you do that not to mention you'd have a more flavorful sauce. I do think a few changes could be made such as adding 4 oz of cheese and seasoned breadcrumbs, a 1/3 cup of milk, half vadalia onion diced and sauteed until softened and italian herb seasoning, 1-28oz can crushed tomatoes and 2-14 oz cans diced tomatoes (italian herb). After adding everything in the pot (I used a crockpot) spoon it out and into a blender to make a smooth sauce. Drop each meatball in and let it stay for at least 1 hour before stirring (to get all that beefy flavor mixed in with the sauce) Other than adding a little more flavor the recipe overall is a great and easy way to make the perfect meatballs especially in a crockpot on low (it helps to maintain a consistent temperature and no need for constant checking)

country:
None
text:
I made this and found the original recipe was far too acidly. Here's my own spin. I found a good bread crumb makes the most out of the meatballs as well as the amount of fat. I used croutons and ground them in my mini food processor and I used ground chuck instead.

I would recommend a 1/2 to a cup of a good red wine to the sauce. If it's good enough for you to drink, it's good enough for you to cook with. Added some oregano and a little more basil and a good pinch of koshet salt. Lastly, to get rid of the acid tomato taste, use more than the recommend teaspoon of sugar. I used believe it or not, ketchup (yes I know, rolling eyes). It was good to go then. If you can go a day, put it in the fridge and preheated the next day. The flavors blend more. Wife and I had left over meatball hoagies. The best.

text:
Wow! Delicious! I've tried several spaghetti sauces on the Allrecipes site. This is the best by far. I made a few changes based on my family's preferences:

(1) We like really meaty sauce, so I browned and added 2 lbs of 85/15 ground beef instead of the meatballs. Before browning, I added double the amount of the parmesan cheese, black pepper, garlic powder and parsley that the orignal meatball recipe called for. I added the beef mixture to the sauce mixture after the sauce had simmered for 90 minutes. 

(2) To the sauce, I added 3-4 tablespoons of Italian Seasoning, doubled the salt and pepper, used 2 bay leaves instead of 1 and added about 1/4 cup of additional sugar. 

Great recipe. We'll definitely be preparing this one again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I grew up in NY eating amazing meatballs from grandma's kitchen (her name, Olive Vinci, should be an indicator of how authentic they were), and this recipe replicated hers almost perfectly (both the sauce and the meatballs).  I am sure that following the recipe precisely would be superb without alteration, but I insist that you should use 80/20 ground chuck (the fat makes for more moisture and flavor), and that you should very lightly brown the meatballs in a cast iron skillet with a small amount of olive oil, as I feel it not only helps bind them, gives them a better color, but also adds texture and flavor that you won't want to live without.  Don't skimp on the San Marzano tomatoes, it is a difference maker (make sure that you read the ingredients carefully, as some are deceptively labeled as San Marzona "style").  Don't search further than this recipe, as none other could  be better...this one is perfection.

Display Name:
mommylove

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! Best spaghetti and meatballs I've ever made. I think not baking the meatballs before putting them in the sauce made them more moist. I altered the recipe as a few others suggested, and substituted one can of whole tomatoes, one can of crushed tomatoes, one small can of sauce, and the tomato paste for the tomato ingredients as listed in the recipe. Another change I made was to cut the salt in half. Even a teaspoon seemed like a lot to me and in the future I'd try a half a teaspoon. Most canned tomatoes have plenty of salt in them, unless you are lucky and can find the low sodium kind. I also think the 1/4 cup of oil could be reduced to a two tablespoons, if desired. I will try that next time. Also, after sauteing the onions and garlic, I put all of the other ingredients together and simmered them for a bit. Then, since I didn't have enough time to simmer on the stove, I just popped everything in the crock pot on low and left it for three hours so I could go out. The meatballs were cooked and everything was delicious. Great recipe!

country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for years and its still a favorite! My family begs me to make it every time I come back in town. I have altered it a bit to my taste, however, as follows: 

No onion in the sauce. I also use a combination of tomato sauce and tomato paste (always hunts) instead of the whole peeled tomatoes, this makes it more "sauce-like" and can easily be altered to the thickness you or your guests prefer. It also requires much less simmer time. I also brown my meatballs first, and then cook them at 350 for 20 min before letting them simmer in the sauce for a bit. These steps cut down the cook time immensely!

text:
Made this with 32 oz of fresh garden tomatoes and a 28 oz can of whole tomatoes.  Blanched and skinned the fresh tomatoes and used a stick blender to combine until 75% smooth.  I added a green pepper and 8oz of sliced mushrooms since I omitted the meat balls; it gave the sauce some extra body.  The only mistake I made was adding the full 2 t of salt while cooking instead of waiting until the sauce was done and adding to taste.  It does taste a bit on the salty side right now.

text:
I made a few modifications to this because I wanted to do a meat sauce, not meatballs.  I also had fresh tomatoes from a friend's garden, so I peeled those and used them in place of canned.  I omitted the onion by personal preference, but did sprinkle in a bit of onion powder.  I made the sauce as directed otherwise.  In the last 30 minutes, I added the ground beef directly to the pan (had 88/12, leaner would work too) along with the parsley.  Just prior to serving I mixed in the Parmesan cheese.  After tasting, I added a little more parmesan and some romano cheese as well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This sauce recipe makes a great baked pasta (NO STOVE TOP COOKING REQUIRED)! I doubled the sauce recipe using 3 whole onions and food processing the tomatoes to break them down a bit. Then layered the uncooked sauce, dry penne pasta (1lb box total for all layers), sauce, penne, sauce (sprinkling a bit of cheese between layers) in a 9x11 pan.  When this recipe is doubled, there is enough sauce to completely cover all the noodles so no go dry. Cooked on 350 for 90 min tightly covered with foil... the pasta was perfectly tender and flavorful.  The sauce did all it's cooking unattended in the oven.  A great weekday entree.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like the fast version. I do cook a special occasion version that is a huge hit! The night before I cut 12 tomatoes, peel and cut up. I use fresh garlic(five cloves at least), one onion, one green pepper, lots of small red and orange peppers, the same seasonings, a dry italian red wine splash, and throw in the crock pot. I then make the meatballs with one pound of lean meat and 1/2 pound of italian sausage. I use an onion, fresh garlic, fresh peppers, fresh parmesan cheese (1/3rd cup) and the other ingredients in the recipe. I allow the meatballs to marinate in the crockpot overnight with sauce. In the morning, I cook all day on low. It's amazing,,,,,,,,,,I like to use a higher quality noodles found in the refrig section when doing the special version. Everyone eats it till they cannot walk. Sometimes you may need to add some tomato paste judging on how you like your sauce and how it is turning out. I also prefer brown sugar over white sugar. My husband likes me to add fresh mushroom to the sauce.

Display Name:
ltcgandy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never rated anything before but decided to.  This recipe is delicious as follows but I also made a few changes and I have to say its my favorite sauce. My husband isn't a fan of "red" sauces but prefers alfredo but even he loved this recipe and had seconds.  It also reheats very well from the fridge or the freezer.  The adjustments I made were I used crushed tomatoes instead of whole, added 1/4 tsp Italian seasoning to the meatballs and the sauce, added 1/4 tsp garlic powder to the sauce, and 1/4 cup dry white wine.  I felt like the wine really gave it more flavor and helped the meatballs from becoming dry.  I actually used some bread that was a few days old and not as "fresh" and it did not dry out at all.  I have also used ground lamb a few times instead of beef for a leaner version.

country:
None
text:
Found this recipe when I was figureing out what the heck to make for lunch. We had all the ingridients, excpet the bay leaf, but it was a smash ! I would give this recipe 5 stars but, I had to make some tweaks, which gives it 4 stars. Things I changed: Instead of putting the meatballs in right away I seasoned them with flour, seasoned salt, oregano, and basil. I set them in the oven, until I needed them for the sauce. I browned the meat balls in a sauce pan with olive oil to seal in the flavor before placing them with the sauce. I am a vegetarian, and this meal was great for my husband, and his father ( who eat meat.) Great dish, will make again !

text:
This was my first attempt at spaghetti sauce. So easy!! The only things I did different is I used Diced tomatoes instead of whole and 2 tsp of sugar instead of one. My husband really likes sweet! I cooked the suace only 30 min on stove top, then poured it over the uncooked meatballs in my crock pot. Let it simmer there for a while, until meatballs were done. Turned out great! No need to cook the meatballs first. Great flavor and very easy. Don't worry about it being a little thin. The meatballs will soak up some of the suace.

text:
I gave this a 3 because I added my own things to make this a 5!  I stayed close to the recipe(using all items) but used brown sugar instead of white (about 3 Tbl. Spns), omitted the salt.  I browned the meatballs in a dutch oven and in the same pot I threw in finely diced mushroom, grn pepper, red pepper and fried that with the garlic/onion.  Used one can of whole/peeled tom, and about 6 romas from my garden peeled/diced.  Then added a can of tomato soup.  Added about 1 cup of tomato juice to the mix as well.  As per recipe added the tom paste at the end and then cooked the meatballs in sauce. MMMM.  Another addition was adding fresh grated parm to the meatball mixture (1/2 cup to 1 cup).  Boyfriend devoured it haha.

city:

country:
None
text:
I chose this recipe because of it's simple no fuss ingredients. I made the following changes because of what I had on hand already. I used one can of crushed tomatoes and one can of diced tomatoes, and decided against the tomato paste. I did not use a bay leaf, and added more garlic and basil, and added a few shakes of paprika to the mix. It ended up being the best sauce I've ever had the pleasure of tasting! The meatballs I followed the recipe but added about 1/4 of a cup of cheese. I also was running short on time so I preheated the oven to 400 degrees and baked them in a shallow pan for 16 minutes or so. They turned out very nice and moist, and perfectly browned. I served them on top of the spaghetti, and my family had nothing but rave reviews! Thank you!

country:
None
text:
This was the first time I cooked anything that wasn't dessert. Both the meatballs and the sauce are very easy to make. If you want more flavor in your meatballs, this recipe gives you a lot of room for customization. The reviewers that rated these as bland and flavorless must've done something wrong. I am a 24 yo graduate student, whose life is spent between books, and not recipe books, so, until I tried this recipe, I honestly thought I couldn't cook, and they came out REALLY GOOD. The sauce is very flavorful, and you can either put in chunky tomatoes or you can add the whole peeled tomatoes and put them in a blender before adding the meatballs, after the first simmer. Also, I didn't simmer the sauce for 90 minutes, I simmered it for an hour and then added the meatballs to simmer for 30 more minutes. They were cooked to perfection. Definitely this is gonna be my go to spaghetti sauce with meatballs recipe.

text:
Delicious! I mixed all the sauce ingredients and simmered in a crock pot for about an hour, then started making the meatballs.  Before putting them in the crockpot, I rolled them in flour and browned them quickly on the stove and it really locked in the flavors! I did use crushed tomatoes instead of whole peeled ones because I don't like my sauce to be too chunky...I also added some extra cayenne to kick it up a notch.  Since the sauce wasn't chunky, as I imagine it would be with the whole tomatoes, I used the left overs for meatball subs! Everyone looved them with pasta but especially the subs!

text:
NEW REVIEW: I'm changing the rating from 1 star to 5 stars. I decided to give this recipe another try and am I ever glad I did! I took one bite and it instantly took me back to my childhood days (sort of like the flashback the restaurant critique had in Ratatouille). These meatballs tasted just like my mom's and they were so soft and tender. I used 1/2 pork, 1/2 beef instead of all beef (that's how mom used to make them), and next time I will add a tsp of salt to the meatballs for more flavour. I think the first time I made these, I had overworked the meat resulting in the tough, dried out meatballs. This time I mixed everything just till blended. I will definitely make this again whenever I crave my mom's spaghetti and meatballs. Thanks, Jeremy! OLD REVIEW: I really had high hopes for this recipe but it turned out to be a disappointment. The listed ingredients are similiar to my mom's meatball sauce, but this didn't even come close to hers. The meatballs were bland, dry and stiff. The sauce tasted fine up until I added the tomato paste at the end, which increased the acidity level again. The high rating is very misleading and I wouldn't even consider this Italian. Sorry but I will not make again.

country:
None
text:
BEST meatball and sauce recipe I've ever made. I always struggle with homemade sauce, it just ends up tasting like tomato paste and water, never with much flavor. Cooking it for 90 minutes lets the flavors of the garlic and onion really cook into the sauce, then the meatballs give the sauce a great flavor as well.

I made it a second time and added an additional can (14 oz) of plain tomato sauce and then upped the basil and garlic a bit, because on my first go, I ended up with more meatballs than I did sauce. It worked out great. The additional 14 ounces was the perfect amount. THANKS for a great meal and a surefire staple recipe in my family!

text:
This recipe tasted like authentic sauce with meatballs! It was fantastic! I did not have dried parsely so I left that out for the meatballs and added dried oregano....I HIGHLY recommend that change!! I also used 1 can whole tomatoes and 1 can diced. At the end of cooking, I added a lot more sugar. I like my sauce a little sweet (like how Prego tastes). You can add more spices at the end to taste if you want it spicer, more sugar, basil, garlic, etc. I served this with angel hair & garlic bread. The only thing I was sad about was that I ran out of meatballs and has a lot of sauce left over. The meatballs were excellent. Thanks so much for this recipe! I can now impress with homemade sauce instead of alwasy using a jar!

text:
This is heaven on a plate! The only change I make is to use half ground beef and half ground sausage. Other than that, exactly as written. These freeze really well, so I always make a double batch. They are ALWAYS a hit!

A tip on making the balls: Always keep your hands moist with water, and keep the tips of your fingers and heels of your hands in contact with each other as you roll them. Perfect meat balls!

text:
I am so happy I found this recipe.  This is the one meal that is guaranteed to get my kids eating.  Sometimes I make the meatballs, sometimes I use premade turkey meatballs and sometimes I just make a meat sauce.  I usually use 28 oz. diced tomatoes and 28 oz. tomato sauce, but have also used the whole tomatoes as well as crushed tomatoes.  But no matter what, it is a hit.  I'm making the sauce right now to use for baked mostaccioli tomorrow night.  It's probably cheaper and definitely easier to use jarred pasta sauce, but there are so many weird unnecessary ingredients.  I feel so good feeding my family a meal completely from scratch.  This is great!

text:
so my dilemma has always to find that perfect balance in a sauce that is not to sweet and makes me say yummm - i am also a vegetarian and i am always looking for ways to find recipes that make everyone in my family happy (im alone on my own little vegetarian island). i made the sauce EXACTLY as written, the meatballs however i had to make adjustments since i don't eat meat so i substituted Vegi burger crumbles in place of the beef and i added some olive oil in the mix and followed the rest of the recipe exactly, took the time to make the "meatballs" and drop them in the pot and after the 30 minute cook time for the "meat" was done i checked the pot and my heart broke a little when i found them all seperated and not meatballish anymore - that being said, this is the best "meat" sauce i have EVER made, the flavor is perfect and i will not change a thing next except taking the time to form little fake "meatballs" AMAZING, and i will probably be making spaghetti alot more often now that i have found the perfect sauce, thanks for sharing!

3371143
Display Name:
Judy Felts Scott
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1602116.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great taste, very rich and tomatoey.  I loved this sauce except for it being so rich.  Most spaghetti sauces I've made would have water added while cooking a long while.  Even though, I give it 5 stars for taste.  The changes I made was:  I used 1/2 ground beef with 1/2 mild Italian sausage.  I also put more garlic powder and Parmesan in the meatballs.  12 meatballs were huge...you could easily make 18.  I also used 1/2 crushed tomatoes instead of whole.  I don't like using whole tomatoes because you have to smash them up and they tend to be tough on the stem end, so diced tomatoes is better.  I used a bit more basil and used about tsp of oregano.  Overall, a great recipe and a keeper.  I doubled this recipe so I could freeze some.   Thanks!

Sauce- I was afraid this would be too "tomato-ey" with not enough spices, but it turned out good! I actually double the recipe for a family get together and did half whole tomatoes and half crushed. Meatballs- GOOD! they were lacking some flavor. I added some italian seasoning, but next time I will get even more creative. Maybe some mozzarella cheese and additional spices. This is a great starter recipe for quick spaghetti and meatballs. If you have the time though, I would suggest a more complex recipe as the flavors are much better. text:
Made a few minor changes:  used 1 lb ground beef plus 1/2 lb ground pork sausage that I had left over from another recipe; used 1/2 cup dry bread crumbs plus 1/2 cup fine ground oats instead of fresh bread crumbs; used 1 can crushed tomatoes and 1 can diced tomatoes in the sauce (because my kids revolt at the sight of large tomatoe pieces in their sauce); made my meatballs slightly smaller and threw it in the crock pot (submerged the raw meatballs in the sauce as best I could without smashing them) - cooked on high for 1 hour and then turned down to low to let it simmer for the rest of the day.  Good stuff and makes a lot - had enough sauce and meatballs left over for meatball subs later in the week.

I LOVED this recipe with my very small changes. I made the meatballs  with 1/2 lb ground beef and 1/2 pound mild italian sausage and doubled the garlic powderbaked them for 30min/350. (The thought of putting raw meatballs in my sauce was icky)  For the sauce, I increased sugar to taste because it cut the very acidic taste of the tomatoes. I also cut the salt in 1/2. I also added 1/2 tsp crushed red pepper. I added my COOKED meatballs to the sauce 15 minutes before sauce was done.  This dish was outstanding and will definitely make again.

Real nice recipe!  I used Muir Glen fire roast whole tomatoes, removing  the stem thingee then crushing them with my hand before adding to the pot.  Also used Muir Glen tomato paste.  For the meatballs, I did use 3/4 pound fresh ground chuck and 1/4 pound fresh ground pork tenderloin...  mixed the cubed meat with the other ingredients and then fed it through the grinder.  They were perfectly seasoned and super tender.  Served with garlic bread and casesar salad.  Yum.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not usually a big fan of spaghetti and meatballs, but this is very good.  As written it has too much salt for me (1493 mg sodium per serving).  I used half the olive oil and half the salt.  I added 3/4 tsp oregano and a  6 inch sprig of fresh rosemary to the sauce.  I used rosemary bread to make the bread crumbs for the meatballs.  I also substituted the whole peeled tomatoes with 1 can crushed and 1 can petite diced tomatoes.  Because I only had 1 egg for a double batch, I was wondering if the raw meat balls would hold together okay as they cooked in the sauce, but it all worked just fine with a great blend of flavors.  I'll make this again and maybe lower the salt a little more.

text:
I would rate this 4.5, it was really good. After reading a lot of the reviews, my changes were I only used 2 tsps of tomato paste and added 1/4 cup red wine, simmer longer for wine taste to burn off. Did not have fresh breadcrumbs so used canned, more parmesan cheese and sauteed onions and fresh basil to the meatballs. Baked meatballs and italian sausage in a 350 oven for 30 mins and then added to the sauce. Also added fresh basil to the sauce, very easy and very impressive. Thank you will use this constantly.

None
text:
Awesome spaghetti sauce!!!!! TY so much. Although it was my first time ever making homemade sauce from scratch, I went through the reviews and altered it just a small bit. I used 1-28 oz can of Rienzi (sp?) peeled plum tomatoes, and 1-28 oz can of 'Hunts' tomato sauce. We're not big on chunky sauce so I tweaked it to have smaller chunks. Additionally, I didn't have any bay leaves, so unfortunately had to omit that ingredient. It was a hit with my very picky 11 yr old and I even gave some to my contractor who's remodeling my kitchen (Tuscan style ;). I used my new Paula Deen cookware and it came out perfect! We're only a family of 3, so I had extra sauce left over from the spaghetti and meatball dinner I made, but I froze the remaining portion I had and will definitely use it for other recipes requiring Italian sauce! This is a keeper and I will be making it from now on.......Kudos to the chef who created this tasty recipe!!!!!!!!!! LOVED it!! 5****

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend requested spaghetti and meatballs because he has never tried it before (he is Japanese) so I made this recipe for him.  I read the other reviews and adjusted slightly.  For the meatballs, I used a mix of pork and ground beef, crushed croutons and real minced garlic.  I also added 2 tsp of Worcestershire sauce.  For the sauce, I used one small onion, only 2 tbsp olive oil, crushed tomatoes instead of whole, 1 tbsp white sugar, replaced the salt with beef bouillon, and added some oregano and parsley.  I was afraid of having greasy sauce, so I baked the meatballs and added them to the sauce later.  It was so good, and my boyfriend loved it!

country:
None
text:
This is so very good!  The meatballs were some of the best I've ever made.  First, I think using fresh bread crumbs is key and cooking the meatballs in the simmering sauce added a dimension of flavor baked/fried meatballs seem to lack.  The only changes I made - based on personal preferences - was substituting one 28oz can of Tomato Puree (try Muir Glen, it's SO fresh tasting) and one 28oz. can of crushed tomatoes with basil for the two cans of whole tomatoes and added sugar only to taste.  I also cooked the sauce in my slow cooker on high and when it began to simmer, added the meatballs.  Thank you so much for posting this recipe - I've been looking for one like this for a long time!

text:
This was a great dinner!!! I have never made my own sauce before so i was a little nervous...After reading other reviews I used one 28oz can of diced tomato and one 28oz of tomato puree and one 8oz can of tomato sauce (garlic, oregano) for some extra spice instead of the whole tomatoes and omitted the tomato paste... I baked the meatballs for 25 mins in a 350 oven then added them in the sauce the last 30 mins of simmering....In the meatballs mixture i also added 1/2 cup of milk they were very moist!!! Thanks for sharing!! definitely a keeper

text:
FINALLY the meatball recipe I have been looking for!  I have been on a quest for some time for the perfect meatball, and this is it.  The only adjustments I made were that I used two tablespoons of grated cheese (I used Parmesand, Roman, Asiago blend b/c that is what I had on hand) and I added 1/2 t. of salt.  I browned them first and then added them to a jar of Prego simply because I didn't have 2 hours to make this sauce.  Came out perfect!

text:
Followed suggestion of another reviewer and put everything except meatballs in the crock pot after cooking onion and garlic.  Cooked on high for 2 hours, low 2 hours, and then added meatballs for one more hour.  I only used 1/2 cup Italian breadcrumbs in meatballs (yielded 12) and added 1 tsp. Italian seasoning to sauce.

text:
Overall, not very time consuming, compared to cooking a sauce all day. Very chunky sauce, sweet in flavor. I used 4 - 14 oz. cans of diced tomato (instead of whole tomato), and can't imagine how much more chunky it would have been with whole tomatoes. Meatballs tasty, but also sweet. I used ground turkey and added a tablespoon of olive oil - so they wouldn't be dry as others commented. May make again with some alterations (more spice), but when in a hurry, will still use jarred sauce and doctor it up.

text:
Excellent!  I made a double batch yesterday.  Only change to the recipe was, as other reviewers suggested, adding an extra tablespoon of grated parmesan to the meatballs, as well as about a teaspoon of Italian seasoning and a teaspoon of garlic powder to the final simmer once the meatballs were added, and I made 41 smaller meatballs instead of 12.  I also let it simmer for an hour instead of half an hour once the meatballs were added.  The only change I would make next time is to add an extra quarter or half cup of onions at the start since they cook way down.  Delicious - thanks for the recipe.

country:
None
text:
This sauce was a big hit in our house! A simple red sauce, but packed with flavor and very easy to throw together.  I made some changes, but only out of necessity (didn't have something on hand) or habit (we use ground venison/beef mixture for just about everything).  The only trick I always use for meatballs is to put them under the broiler for about 8 - 10 minutes (turn them halfway through) then add them to the sauce as it simmers on the stovetop.  The meatballs get a little browned and make the sauce taste even better.  (Thanks Mom for the tip!). Thanks to Jeremy for posting this terrific recipe~ !

This was a very easy and very good recipe.  My husband doesn't like any spaghetti sauce other than Ragu...he actually liked this!  I made the following changes...substituted ground bison for the beef, used 1/2 cup whole wheat breadcrumbs and 1/2 cup oatmeal for the meatballs. text:
I made some minor changes to this excellent recipe.  I used fresh parsley in meatballs and sauce.  Used 1 cup of milk for breadcrumbs to soak in before adding to the meatball mix.  Rolled my meatballs in breadcrumbs before placing in 350 degree oven for 25 minutes.  When I took cooked meatballs from oven, I addedto sauce and let it cook for 2 hours on low heat.  So Good!

text:
First, Great recipe Jeremy and thank you for sharing :) I utilized this recipe for the meatballs only as I have my own traditional sauce.  Anyway, I read all the reviews,,those that want more flavor, use 1/2 Italian Sausage instead of all hamburger, those that want it more moist, throw in some spaghetti sauce from your meal before you make the meatballs.  And yes I did brown the meatballs just so they held their shape. For the most part the meatballs were still raw when I put them in the sauce.  Excellent meatballs and I will make them again and again because my husband prefers meatballs with spaghetti along with my neighbor who is an older full Italian treasure.  She is who gave these the thumbs up!  Thanks again Jeremy!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I only used the meatball recipe and I thought they were very good. I added chopped onion and green pepper to them, and instead of simmering them in the sauce, I spread just a little vegetable oil in the bottom of my electric skillet and lined up the raw meatballs in it. I covered with some additional chopped green peppers and onions, covered and cooked on 350 until browned and cooked through. I then poured spaghetti sauce evenly over the top of them and sprinkled shredded cheddar cheese and grated parmasan cheese over the sauce. I then covered and simmered until the sauce was warm and cheese was melted. If you cook the meatballs in a skillet though, keep a close eye on them so the bottoms don't burn, turn if needed. Great cheesy spaghetti and meatball dish!

Made meatballs 1/2 lb ground beef, 1/2 lb Bob Evans Hot Italian Sausage.  Used 2/3 c. italian breadcrumbs and 1/4 c grated parmesean cheese & half can italian seasoned tomato sauce.  Then followed the rest of the ingredients.  The meatballs were flavorful and moist.  For the sauce, I used 2 cans crushed tomatoes, followed the rest of the ingredients and used the remaining 1/2 can tomato sauce.  The meatballs really did flavor the sauce nicely.  The sauce did taste a little too salty, so next time will reduce to 1 tsp salt.  Thanks for a great tasting recipe.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe a lot!  Took the advice of one reviewer and turned it into a slow cooker meal.  I put all the sauce ingredients together in the morning and then turned it on at about 275 degrees for 6 hours.  I put the sauce through a blender just before adding the meatballs  cause I don't like big cooked tomato pieces (even though I used 5 cans of diced tomatoes and 5 of whole tomatoes). I took the advice of adding a can of tomato sauce too.  I didn't use fresh bread crumbs for the meatballs as I couldn't find any, so I just used dried ones instead.  Also, I forgot the garlic powder in them, so I just dumped a bunch extra in the sauce along with some Italian seasoning and more salt and pepper.  I also added 2 extra eggs to the meat balls, but I was making the recipe x5(not sure I'd do that next time though).  I added the meatballs an hour before serving and cranked the heat to 350.  Turned out great!  Especially served over whole wheat pasta.  Yum

text:
This recipe is one of the favorites I have found so far for pasta sauces, and I have tried quite a few in the past few months. I did make some adjustments (as does everyone on this site). I used 2 28 oz cans of crushed tomatoes (not whole tomatoes) - mostly personal preference. When making the meatballs, I used 1/2 cup of crushed Club crackers because I ran out of breadcrumbs (had like 1/8 of a cup or something... so useless!) I then added 1/4 cup of milk to the meatballs. Oh, and I also used 1/2 lb ground pork and 1/2 lb ground beef as well as fresh parsley (didn't have any dried on hand, and fresh is so cheap anyway). I cooked the meatballs in the sauce, which I agree was a great method of cooking. This recipe is fantastic, and I will use it again. Thanks!!

country:

text:
Fantastic! I was looking to make homemade meatballs and this recipe looked perfect. Now, I won't have to buy, pre-made sauce ever again.   For the sauce I used 2 (28 oz) cans crushed tomatoes.  My sons don't like chunky tomatoes in thier sauce.  I also added oregano and thyme along with the bay leaf in the beginning.  I did not add any salt. For the meatballs, I used 1.5 pounds of 85% lean ground beef.  I also started out with 1/2 cup italian seasoned bread crumbs and 4 Tbls. shredded Parmesean (we like cheese).  I've learned you can always add ingredients but it is difficult to take away.  I found though that I did't need to add any more bread crumbs.  I also added some saueteed onions and minced garlic for more flavor. This mixture made 16 meatballs.  My sons did comment that they looked large, I thought they looked normal.  Maybe next time, I'll make them smaller.  Cooking the meatballs in the sauce was awesome.  I simmered my sauce for 90 minutes, added the meatballs and cooked them for about 45 minutes.   I made Garlic Bread Mama Rita's Way! from this website, to go with our meal. My son's gobbled everything up!!

I followed the recipe exactly as written with the exception of using diced tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes.  The end result was not as good as I'd hoped.  The sauce was runny and not thick like we typically enjoy.  I didn't like the big chunks of tomatoes and if I had used the whole tomatoes, it would have been worse. I liked the fact that I didn't have to precook them.

This was a great recipe!!  I just thought it was a little oily.  I took out the onions so that may have been why.  Next time I make it I will cut down the olive oil because hamburger is naturally oily any ways.  Plus I couldn't find dried basil, so I just used Italian seasoning instead.  I omitted the parsley in the meat balls and added more cheese.  I would also suggest adding a little more tomato paste to the mix.  I pureed my tomatoes before adding the meatballs to the sauce.  It didn't say in the recipe to do that.

text:
MMMM! I loved it. I would definately recommend this recipe to anyone.  The sauce was very hearty & flavorful. The only change I made to the sauce was I used chopped tomatoes instead of whole and I pureed them, I dont like a real chunky sauce.  I did make a few changes to the meatballs, I used a ground beef, pork, & veal mixture, I doubled the parmesan cheese 1 tbsp just didnt look like enough, and I also added 1/4 cup milk.  I too was weary about adding the meatballs directly to the sauce without browning first, I did, but I simmered it for an hour after adding the meatballs. I dont think I will make any other changes next time I absolutely loved it. I think I will try the meatballs on a sub roll with some shredded mozzerella as others have suggested, sounds like a mean meatball sub to me.

text:
I was on the hunt for a meatball recipe and came across this. Excellent! I doubled the recipe and ended up with about 28 good sized meatballs. Didn't add a thing to it.I didn't have any lean ground beef left so I used regular. I did brown the meatballs on all sides in olive oil and instead of cooking them in a sauce I just placed them on my broiler pan and baked them at 350 for a bit. They came out crispy yet moist. Plus the grates in the brolier pan allowed icky fat to drain away! Great recipe!

text:
Fantastic basic sauce!  I like to use fresh basil (or the refrigerated basil in a tube) instead of dried. The flavor is great. I always add a generous amount of garlic as well.  Don't try to cut back the cooking time.  The tomatoes will cook down and break up completely to thicken the sauce the longer you cook them.  Thanks for the recipe!  It is my staple recipe for tomato sauce.

I prepared the sauce and cooked it in a slow cooker on low for six hours, then I added the meatballs and cooked for an extra hour on high. I found the sauce a bit bland (It needed more seasoning, although I did add some tomatoe juice to it in case it became too thick in the slow cooker, and a can of mushrooms because we like them) but the meatballs were really good (I added a couple of dashes of worcestershire sauce and hot sauce to the mix). Overall a good recipe but needs a bit of modifications for my taste.

text:
All the reviewers are correct - what a great recipe! Sauce was amazing and the meatballs were moist and delicious (not only in the sauce but also in meatball subs the next day). I used 28oz peeled whole and 28oz Italian diced tomatoes, added 1/2 chopped green pepper to the onions. After an hour cooking, I added 1/4tsp red pepper flakes. After 90 min. I also added some Italian seasoning, onion powder, oregano, and garlic powder, some Pinot Noir and 2 Dorot cubes of frozen basil. In the meatballs I was a bit under one pound of ground beef and added 1.5 mild Italian sausage in meat mixture. Really tasted amazing! This will be a staple in my household!

3256244
Display Name:
Nitejazmine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/134141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GUYS!!!This is by far...the best and the "it".
Let me tell you my variations that you would love. I follow some advice from other members.
MEATBALLS: I added the following plus the recipe given: 
I did 2 lbs of lean ground beef..
1/2 C parmessan
1/4 C beef broth (to keep it moist)
1 eggs
Italian seasoning= 2Tbsp
(basil,oregano,thyme,marjoram, etc)
2 tsp garlic salt
Mixed them with your bare hands (make sure to wash ur hands really good before mixing and after)
then make a meat ball...(2 lbs - 24 meatballs)
get a  freezer ziploc and put 1/4 C flour inside. Then put all the meat balls in the floures ziploc to coat meat balls.
 Get a pan and spay a lil bit of olive oil and spread the meatballs. Bale in a preheated 250 degres (1.5-2hrs) when it becomes a little brown and turn over. Once its cook then set aside.
SAUCE:
I sauteed 1 big chopped onion
5 cloves of chopped garlic
Heres the trick:
Then I got my slow cooker turned them to High...when the garlic and onion are transparent then transfer them to the slow cooker...the add the following:
I learned that if you have no tomatoes(which I dont have) the best thing you can use is  salsa...yes its SALSA.. 
So I got my mild salsa
2 Cups of Salsa (from costco)
2 C of prego pasta sauce (from costco)
1.5 C of Beef broth
1 T garlic powder
simmer for 3 hrs...reduce to low...then add the tomato paste basil, salt, sugar ground pepper (as per recipe shows)
and 12 meatballs for another 1 hr.
Now..you can start the sauce as you bake the meatbal

4 stars is for the sauce! So tasty. I did add about a half cup of red wine to the sauce and a few splashes to the meatball mix. I also added several spoonfuls of the sauce to the meatballs to ensure they wouldn't be dry...definitely worked! However, even with the addition of green bell peppers, lots of garlic, the meatballs didn't have enough umph for me. I'll definitely make the sauce again but next time I think I'll look to a different meatball recipe.

text:
Seriously, I am part Sicilian and this recipe rivals all meatballs I have ever eaten at my Nan's or any other family member's! The sauce is nice and thick and the meatballs were very flavorful. One thing I do is add somewhere between 1/2 and 1 cup of warm water to my meatball mix, until it is moist. This ensures moist meatballs after cooking. I also added a teaspoon of salt to the meatball mix. Great recipe!

only used the sauce recipe. Ihave been doing more "natural" cooking (hardly any premade items) and was looking for a good spaghetti sauce. I might try others to have something to compare, but I loved that my picky 12 yr old (who will only eat Prego sauce) are this and never said a word. There was none left!

text:
This is a fantastic sauce, and we especially liked the meatballs. I used half ripe summer tomatoes and doubled the garlic in the sauce, and added 1/4 c of chicken stock - I think this really added to the end result!  In the meatballs, we used finely diced chopped garlic instead of powder, and we were careful not to overwork the meat and made the meatballs smaller (about an inch diameter).  Overall - thumbs up, great recipe!

Display Name:
crazycatlady - "CCL"
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/229096.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used garlic salt, onion powder & some oregano in the meatballs & I used cracker crumbs rather than bread crumbs.  To keep the meatballs from being dry, I added a small can of tomato juice. I used basil in place of the parsley and added a little more parm b/c I used closer to 1.5 pounds of ground beef.  I baked the meatballs at 350 for 25 minutes and just added them to the sauce at the very end to coat and flavor well.  For the sauce, I sauteed the onion and garlic in "bruschetta" olive oil. I used two 14.5 oz. cans of Italian diced tomatoes, 1 can of Hunt's tomato sauce for lasagna and one 26 oz. can of Hunt's Roasted garlic and onion Spaghetti sauce.  It needed just a bit more sugar for the tartness so I added in a little brown sugar.  I also added some oregano with the basil. I am sure the recipe is still quite good as stated, but  I made these changes after reading some of the reviews and also to use up some of the items I already had in my pantry.    Thanks for sharing the recipe!

My husband has an aversion to onions and my two best friends are allergic, so I searched high and low for a decent onionless meatball recipe. I've never made the sauce (always just used a jarred kind), but the meatballs are DELISH. We use them for spaghetti and for meatball hoagies. 

The only thing I do different is like quadruple the amount of parmesean cheese. I don't measure it, I just dump in a bunch - maybe 1/8 or 1/4 cup?

Anyway, thanks so much for this recipe! I've been making it for years and everyone raves.

text:
I tried real hard to follow the recipe exactly to give it a fair review.  I ended up adding more seasoning (Italian and Spaghetti Sauce Seasoning), 1 T brown sugar (but could've even used more) pureed the tomatoes (I already substituted one of the cans for crushed tomatoes).  The meatballs were perfect but there could've been more, 1 1/2 to 2 times the amount.  So overall it was a good recipe to tweek to your individual tastes, thanks for sharing!  Oh, and I used 2 slices of fresh bread and ground them up in the food processor (tearing them by hand would work too), you do NOT want to use regular bread crumbs!

I made the sauce only, and used it in a baked ziti recipe.  Fabulous and easy!  I added 1 (6 ounce) can tomato sauce, 1 teaspoon worcestshire, and for spices I used 1 teaspoon minced fresh rosemary, 1 teaspoon dried basil, 1 teaspoon oregano, 1 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper, 1/2 teaspoon dried chives, 1/2 teaspoon paprika, 1/4 teaspoon parsley, and a pinch cumin.  It was just a little too salty, so I will reduce the salt to 1 tsp next time.

text:
Our family loves this recipe! And there is no need to let the sauce simmer for 90 minutes. After adding the tomatoes, salt, sugar, and bay leaf bring the mixture to a boil. Then proceed with adding the tomato paste, basil, pepper, and meatballs. Simmer for another 30 minutes like the recipe says and you have a delicious....and much quicker dish for dinner! Thank you for this new family favorite!

text:
I have been making this for a few years now. I finally decided to sing up and post my review on one of my fav recipies. I did however make a few changes. I used 28 ounce crushed tomatoe, 28 ounce tomatoe puree, and 28 ounce tomatoe sauce. I left out the paste, I don't like my sauce too thick. I also made this recipe in my slow-cooker and let it cook for 6 hours and put the meatballs in for the last hour and a half. Truly the best! I'm considering to adding a chopped green bell pepper the next time I make it.Enjoy!!

text:
This recipe as-is is ok.  To make true Italian meatballs, you need the trinity -one third each of ground veal, beef, and pork.  Since ground veal is difficult to find, I usually substitute it with Italian sausage.  To keep the meatballs moist, I usually add half a cup of cream or milk - similar to meatloaf recipes.

text:
I only made the meatballs from this recipe.  My daughter decided on her 5th birthday that she wanted spaghetti and meatballs for her special supper.  I only had 1/2 hour to prep supper and no time to make a special trip to the grocery store.  This recipe was a life saver.  The only change I made was adding some salt and extra cheese.  The birthday girl and everyone else thought they were great.  Maybe they aren't "Authentic" enough for some people but the fact that they are made from simple ingredients most people have on hand and they take a relatively small amount of time to make and they taste good makes it a keeper recipe for me.  Will definitely make this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was pretty good. I did make some changes. I used home canned tomatoes and drained them before I measured 28 oz. I did use 1 tsp of italian seasoning in the tomato sauce. I used 2 eggs in the meatball mixture and it did not seem too dry to me. I cooked the meatballs in the sauce, but added them so they cooked for about 1 hour instead of the 30 minutes it called for. The meatballs came out nice and tender and were delicious. I did end up cooking the sauce for a total of 2 1/2 hours because I wanted it to cook down a bit more and become thicker. I used 6 oz of tomato sauce instead of the paste just because that's what I had in the house. I will definately make this again. Great recipe to make for Sunday dinner when its raining outside! It would be great as a Meatball Sub Sandwich. I made the garlic cheese flatbread (also on this site) to go with it. Thanks for the great recipe Jeremy!

text:
Very good!  My first attempt at meatballs of any kind, and they turned out so well.  My daughter requested spaghetti and meatballs after seeing it in a book so I found this recipe.  I used 97% lean ground beef with great results.  I also used whole wheat bread crumbs (made my own in my food processor).  I had slightly over a pound of ground beef, and made 16 meat balls.  I used half no-salt tomatoes and omitted the extra salt from the sauce.  Served with steamed asparagus and Garlic Cheese Flatbread from this site.  We had a guest for dinner and he enjoyed this too.

I have made this several times and I would give this 10 stars if I could. Cooking the meatballs in the sauce makes this easy and delicious.  I use this spaghetti sauce with all dishes that call for spaghetti sauce because I love it so much.  Make sure that you let the sauce simmer for the 90 minutes recommended in the recipe.  This really lets the flavours melt together.  Mmmmmmmmmmm... enjoy!

text:
I only make the meatballs because I have my own sauce recipe, but they are superb! I did make a few changes: I reduced the bread crumbs to 3/4 cup because 1 cup makes them too dry. I also add 1/4 cup of shredded six-cheese Italian blend (which you can buy at any grocery store) and add a little extra parmesan. The meatballs come out moist and flavorful, and my entire family loves them!

text:
The sauce was easy and had a great flavor.  Next time, I'll use diced tomatoes vs. whole b/c they don't simmer long enough for the whole to break down to edible pieces.  I also added 9 garlic cloves since my husband and I love garlic and oregano along with the basil.  Regarding the meatballs, I will bake them next time before adding them to the sauce mixture to reduce fat (they were too squishy).  Otherwise, this is an easy recipe w/ great flavor.

text:
Like some other reviewers, I only made the meatballs, and I think they have almost the perfect texture. My husband thought they were a bit bland, but I think they compliment a favorite sauce very well. They were very easy to put together in a food processor, I just pulsed it until the ingredients were blended. I didn't bake them first - they cooked up great in my sauce without falling apart. I should try the sauce to be fair, but I just don't think I would be able to stand making a spaghetti sauce without red wine and oregano!

userID:
1081088
Display Name:
Kathleen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I scaled this for 90 servings and made it for our church potluck and got many positive comments! My hospitality team got together and made the meatballs (about 300 of them)a day ahead of time and they kept very well in the refrigerator until I was ready to use them.  They smelled great and had a nice texture and flavor, and held together very well while cooking. It was great not having to brown them first.  I took other people's advice and used diced tomatoes instead of whole ones.  It was a good decision.  The only suggestion I have is that if you scale it to make a large quantity, use your judgement on the amount of olive oil to use when you saute your onion and garlic.  I used what it called for and it was too much - made the sauce a little too oily. I made sure to use ground beef for the meatballs and not ground chuck or ground sirloin. I think that makes a big difference in the outcome and I made sure to use soft, fresh bread crumbs - we made them in a small food processor.  All in all it was a great recipe and I will definately make it again.

region:

country:
None
text:
BRAVO! This was absolutely great! My American boyfriend had been longing for this dish, so I went ahead and did it. First time- excellent, but with a few changes it was even better!

I cut down on the breadcrumbs and doubled the parmesan and (FRESH!!! Use ONLY fresh herbs and double the amount!) parsley for the meatballs. To the sauce, I added a couple of tablespoons of cooking cream which added immensly to the flavor and texture.
Penne pasta, those tender meatballs in the velvety, creamy tomatoe-sauce... it's a dish to die for!!!! 

Try it. It takes some time, but it's worth every second. And make sure to have some fresh, warm garlic-bread to suck up the sauce with!

Tina from Uppsala, Sweden

I do think that a cup of breadcrumbs was a little too much, and next time I think I'll use Italian breadcrumbs instead of plain. They needed a little more kick. I also had to use jar spaghetti sauce, because I didn't have everything I needed to make the sauce. I will try it next time.  Really good!

text:
Scrumptious! I add tomato paste in once garlic and onion is tender and fry together for at least 5 minutes before adding tomatoes, etc. This cuts the acidity and brings out the natural sweetness of the tomato eliminating the need to add sugar. Mixing 1/3 cup or so of the pasta water into your sauce just before you drain the pasta puts it over the top!

I followed the recipe for the meatballs, only substituting Italian seasoned breadcrumbs instead of fresh) but then I got lazy & cheated Big Time - I used 2 jars of Kroger's sauce instead of making it.
But it turned out amazing!!
(Seriously!)
In fact, it was SO good, we ended up eating WAY too much...
And thus began what is now known as "The Great Spaghetti Coma of 2019" 
15 minutes after we ate, we both fell asleep and didn't move for 14 hours straight!
Delicious

text:
I made this last night.  I basically doubled the recipe as I had one lb. of beef and one lb. of pork.  I only used one can of tomato paste.  I did not have stale bread so I had to use seasoned bread crumbs.   I baked the meatballs for about half an hour in the oven then plopped them in the sauce.  My meatballs were about 3 inch.  I actually did not do the spaghetti.  I made meatball sandwiches because I had awesome Jersey corn and felt it went better with the sandwiches.  These were the best meatballs I have ever made.   My husband agreed.  I woke up this morning thinking I'd heat some up for breakfast.  But I think I'll wait until lunch.  Forgot to mention that I added a splash of red wine to the sauce.  Definitely two thumbs up!

text:
The meatballs and sauce were good.  I think some of the chefs that complained that the meatballs were dry might have used dried breadcrumbs instead of fresh bread crumbs.  I added 1 t of dried basil and fresh garlic to the meatballs.  To the sauce I add more basil and add some oregano and cook it covered for 1 1/2 hrs, and add meatballs and cook 1/2 hr longer.  I use my immersion blender or my hands to crush San Marzano whole tomatoes, also a little red wine 1 cup , Chianti.  Just a few   differences to make it my own.  Thank You for a great recipe.  Also, I add 1 teas.  of salt to the meatballs.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2938538.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe for sauce and meatballs. 
Add mushrooms, veggies or whatever you want to customize things to your liking. Much better than those quick sauce recipes that have many of the same ingredients but leave out the longer cooking times to make it quick.
Meatballs can use some extra time too. Mix, cover and refrigerate. 2-3 hrs or over night. 
Form into balls and place on a rimmed cookie sheet. Bake at 400 degrees for 10 min and add to sauce when itâs time to add the tomato paste.
I do a 3 to 1 ratio with the meatballs tho. 3 parts ground beef to 1 part Italian sausage and donât forget to use the fresh breadcrumbs. It keeps the meatballs moist along with the Italian sausage which also bumps up the flavor.

country:

text:
Made it! Sort of. You may as well say it was a different recipe, but this was the inspiration. First, I chopped 1/2lb bacon which needed to be used up. Then, I prepped the meatballs per this recipe while the bacon browned. Spaghetti noodles cooking simultaneously. However, I had no bread crumbs (nor some of the other ingredients), but I did have plenty of Ritz crackers instead. While the bacon was browning, I tossed in the remaining cracker crumbs from a partial roll (barely 1/4 cup), and mixed in a pinch of onion and garlic powders, as well as Parsley, Then, I added the meatballs and 2 jars (24 oz. ea.) of Classico Sweet Basil Spaghetti Sauce. I the added a 1/2lb Braum's Pork Sausage (rolled in balls) by family request and simmered for near 1 hour. (my heat was too low the first 15 minutes). The meatballs were quite soft, but that was actually perfect for me since I have 2 new temporary crowns. So, in using the premade sauce, overall cook time was cut in at least half. I also made garlic toast by lightly spraying butter on bread and placing in toaster. Once removed, sprinkle pinch of garlic powder and salt to taste.
Top spaghetti with Parmesan cheese and a sprinkle of parsley for color.

text:
I modified this recipe to use what I had. I didn't have eggs, so I skipped them. I had fresh tomatoes so used twice as much tomato and simmered them for about a day. I followed the advice of Simon and Garfunkle. I added about 2 tea spoons each of dry  "parsley, sage, rosemary, and thyme" to the meat balls and to the sauce. I doubled everything to feed 12 people. I made some big meat balls like ones I like in Italian restaurants and some small ones like the frozen ones I get at COSTCO and Smart and Final. The little ones work better for a crowd. The big ones work better for me.

text:
This recipe took a long time to cook, but was easy to make. I followed the recipe, except I took the lid off the pan for a while and let the tomato sauce cook down. My husband loved it, but would have liked it thicker still (he wants it to stick to the pasta better). Oh, I tasted and added a bit more sugar to offset the acidity of the tomatoes. I will definitely be making this again, possibly with more seasoning. We ate half, and I put the other half in a Ziplock for another dinner. Yay! Update - 1-18-19 - I thawed the second half and heated it up tonight. I put it in a large skillet and let it warm uncovered for about 45 minutes. The sauce thickened quite a lot and I'll be making it again. Bumping my rating to a five, now that I know I can thicken the sauce.

userID:
11541774
Display Name:
Boris A. Bear
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

6
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1370413.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My original review seems to have disappeared. Anyhow, there is the basis for a good recipe in here but I'm only giving it 3 stars because I feel there are a lot of tweaks needed.

First off, the recipe doesn't instruct to brown the meatballs in the pan first. This is a critical step to a great spaghetti and meatballs as cooking raw meatballs in the sauce will not be as good. Just get a hot pan and brown them on all sides and reserve to finish cooking in the sauce.

There's a bit too much onion, 1/2 cup is plenty and I also feel that the sauce is a bit too thick. I had to add some red wine. Also, the cooking time is a bit exaggerated. This doesn't need 2 hours if your meatballs are browned, 60 minutes in total (30 minutes to thicken and 30 minutes to finish cooking meatballs is enough)

Seasoning is very personal so I won't mention it. Taste your sauce as you make it to find the taste you like. I like a little heat so I added crushed red pepper flakes. I also include fresh basil in my sauce. Good base, but needs a little work to be great.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-02T15:08:25.15
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This is the first recipe that I have ever used for making homemade spaghetti sauce (I have always just bought the premade stuff off the shelf at the grocery store), and it has been a huge hit!  My children and I don't care for tomato chunks, so I puree the tomatoes in blender before putting them in the pot for the sauce.  Other than that, I follow the recipe as stated.  I have made it about 5 times now and it always turns out great.  
I give it 4 instead of 5 stars only because, for my personal taste, I might adjust the salt a bit (add more) and add some basil or oregano for more flavor.  But, the recipe as written is solid and very enjoyable!

userID:
1414774
Display Name:
AUSSIEMUM1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
45

0
madeRecipesCount:
223
favoritesCount:
423
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/23546.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE TIP: Add the salt and sugar right at the end of cooking this sauce! Why? Because you add the salt and sugar at the start, but then the flavors change with continued cooking and all of a sudden it's not enough salt or sugar. So you add more and cook more, then find yourself adding more salt and sugar as the flavor balance has changed once again. So add the herbs, but not the sugar and salt until the very end, like right before you serve, so you don't increase your salt and sugar intake to unhealthy levels, and you might find that once the tomatoes cook longer, you don't need as much salt and sugar as some tomatoes can be sweet, others watery etc. I make this sauce with Chef John's Italian Meatballs. They go really well together. I double the tomatoes though, and because it's very salty, I add an extra teaspoon of sugar. So I use 4 tins of tomatoes, 4 tsp salt, 4 tsp white sugar. I don't double the oil or the onions or the garlic. I do double the basil and the tomato paste. I once tried doubling the oil, garlic and onion but it didn't improve the flavours. The reason I add more tomatoes is because I have a large family and need more sauce for the meatballs.  I love how easy this recipe is.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-05-03T20:25:20.723
helpfulCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3158466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the recipe as I had a kilo of extra lean ground beef and we like to use leftover meatballs and sauce for subs.
I love this method as it is easy, and makes the meatballs so tender and flavourful.
For the meatballs I used 1/2 cup Panko breadcrumbs as it was what I had, and fresh garlic for the garlic powder.
For the sauce I reduced the salt to 1/4 tsp as I am on a low sodium diet. I added celery and mushrooms with the onions as well. The sauce was quite thick so I added some water and tomato sauce that I had.
My family really enjoyed the meatballs and spaghetti!
#AllrecipesAllstarsCanada
#InternationalFavourites

text:
Good basic recipe..easy to customize to make your own. Due to diet I left the breadcrumbs out of the meatballs (I therefore baked them for 5 mins at 425 to help set up before putting in sauce). I doubled the basil and used a while onion. My husband doesn't like tomato chunks so I lightly pureed the sauce with an immersion blender. Tasted it at the end it was good...but decided to add some basil pesto and red chili peppers to it to suite my need for intense flavors..:)

text:
This is the best spaghetti and meatballs Iâve ever had! I make it at least twice a month and itâs a big hit with my four year old son. I think the original recipe is genius and you wonât believe how delicious it tastes and smells when you see how simple it is to make. I do make some minor changes for convenienceâs sake: I prefer cans of ground tomatoes with tomato juice added. I skip the tomato paste and add about a cup of water so itâs not too thick. Instead of parsley which I donât often have on hand I add dried oregano and basil to the meatballs. I add garlic salt instead of garlic powder. I also tend to have no breadcrumbs when I decide to make this recipe so I use multigrain pita bread which I blitz in my blender- instant bread crumbs! I tend to have this in my freezer so I just defrost one or two medium size ones. I find this makes the meatball soft and moist.

country:
None
text:
I was having a group of 12 guests over and I made lasagna and this recipe. I decided to throw 2 cans of crushed tomatoes in the crock pot while I was finishing the lasagna. I made only a few modifications to this recipe I added a 16 oz. can of plain tomato sauce to the cooked down sauce. I sautÃ©ed onions and garlic, transferred some sauce from the crock pot over to add the tomato paste, (2 6oz. cans), and added one tsp. baking soda, one teaspoon honey instead of white sugar. Moved the sautÃ©ed mixture into the crock pot. I added fresh parsley sprigs as suggested by another review. I doubled the meatball recipe, added Panko Italian bread crumbs and 1/4 cup milk, refrigerated it until I was ready to bake them 350 for 20 minutes. Added the meatballs to the sauce. Everything turned out delicious!

userID:
17376923
Display Name:
Mike Burns
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4322151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this dish yesterday, EXCELLENT!  The only modification was I used 1/2 lb. of spicy Italian sausage and 1 lb. of ground beef.  I also let it  simmer for 2 hours vs. the one hour.  The flavors were amazing!
When I went to the store for the ingredients, I could not find a 16 oz. can of any type of tomatoes, so I bought a 28 oz. can.  When I cooked the sauce, I only used 16 oz. from the can, intending to freeze the rest.. (I noticed in some of the reviews that others had used a 28 oz. can from the start.)  So when I needed more sauce on Day 2, I just added the other 12 oz. to the mix. BIG MISTAKE! It obviously diluted the sauce, but also lessened the "wow factor" of the first day.  So, my advice: use only 16 oz. of tomatoes and if you need more, start a NEW batch of sauce!

text:
I like to add veggies like broccoli and carrots to my meatballs to make this a healthier meal for my son and the family. I also steam the veggies for just a few minutes (3-4) before adding them to the beef. If you decide to do this, I'd also suggest adding a lot more of garlic, oregano, italian spice mix and maybe 1/4 tsp of salt. I also like to add just a little milk to keep the meatballs moist. Then I throw them in the oven at 350 degrees for 20 minutes. Mangia!

This is a great base recipe to experiment with.  I added baby Bella mushrooms that I ground up in the food processor.  They add some hidden nutrition (no one knows they are there! ) and nice texture and flavor.  I also used a mix of turkey and beef.  For the sauce, I used crushed tomatoes and tomato puree. I was short on time and just added dried chopped onion instead of fresh.  The results were delish! Sometimes I also add carrots that I pulverized in the food processor for added sweetness and nutrition.  I will be using this recipe again for sure!

I would say that, if you have the time to execute this recipe fully, it is totally worth it and will ruin your affinity for sauce in a can forever!

text:
I have been trying to replicate the meatballs my mother used to make, so I have been searching for recipes that I think might have been like hers. I do remember that she used fresh bread, so this recipe caught my eye. The first time I tried it, I followed the recipe, but the meatballs were much harder and drier than I liked. So the second time I took someone's advice and soaked the fresh bread crumbs in 1/2 cup of milk. This did the trick, I am pleased. I also added a little extra garlic powder. I would make them again. The sauce was also very good as is.

text:
Pretty much followed the recipe as is. One thing i did change was using diced tomatoes instead of whole peeled (cause thats what I had on hand). Halfway thru the three hour simmer (another change based on another reviewers recommendation) I turned off the burner, let it cool for a bit, then threw it in my blender for a smoother sauce. I was a bit skeptical about just adding the raw meatballs into the sauce but they cooked up just fine. I think next time I make this I will do something to the meatballs to jazz them up a bit. I will probably also add some type of mushroom to the sauce. Served this with a french bread recipe also on this site, and a green salad.

text:
I've made this my new go-to sauce. It has a wonderful full flavor and is very authentic tasting. The only substitution for me is that I use puree instead of whole or diced tomatoes because one kid in my family will relentlessly pick out the tomato bits when I make it that way. It's better tasting the way the recipe calls for whole tomatoes, or with diced as I have also tried, but the puree keeps me sane!

We made this sauce for our Cub Scout Blue and Gold Banquet.  I had made this before for my picky eater grandsons and when they all loved it I knew it would work for Cub Scouts.  Using allrecipes modifer, I modified it for 100 people.  I did leave out the bay leaves, I didn't want to have to try to find 20 bay leaves before serving.   Everyone loved it and wanted to know what brand it was.   I thought it was missing something and realized it was the bay leaves.    Excellent sauce, easy to make and loved by all.  I have made the meatballs before for my family and everyone loved them too.  This one is definitely a keeper.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the sauce only of this recipe (to have with chicken parmesan).  It was very good, and I am writing a review to remind myself to make it again.  I doubled the recipe and have some in the freezer now.  I had to make a few substitutions based on what I had on hand, and I was sure we would want a little more seasoning.  First, I didn't have 4 big cans of whole tomatoes, so I used 1 (28 oz) can whole, 1 (28 oz) can crushed, and 4 (14 oz) cans various diced tomatoes.  I also added ~1 tsp or so Italian seasoning mix and ~1/2 tsp garlic powder before the first simmer.  Then I added an additional 1.5 tsp oregano along with the basil and pepper before the second simmer.  I thought it was a little sweet and probably won't add quite as much sugar next time (although this seems like so little), but it's definitely a keeper, and I will certainly make it again.

This is a really great recipe! I will never go back to jar sauces again. Slight changes I made, I used half ground beef and half ground pork for the meatballs. I used twice as much garlic and onions, as we are want to do here in New Orleans. When I added the meatballs I also added 1 tsp Oregano. Next time I will use 1 can of whole tomatoes and 2 cans of diced tomatoes. Really flavorful sauce! I've never cooked meatballs that way, I usually brown them first, but they came out so tender and yummy! Try this one in case you ever have to cook for a bunch of guys one day all sleeping on mattresses. (Yes, that was a Godfather reference;)

This is truly the best sauce ever!! I make it exactly as written, but I make 1 1/2 to a double recipe to feed all my troop always using 2 lbs of ground beef. text:
I doubled the recipe as a whole. I double the amount of parmesan cheese and garlic powder in the meatballs. I also used fresh parsley in the meatballs. Remember 3 times fresh to replace the dried herbs. Dried herbs have a stronger flavor. Also I did follow the recipe and used fresh bread crumbs but pulsing some very fresh rolls in my food processor. I used fresh basil in the sauce. Again, three to one when replacing fresh with dry herbs. Cooking the meatballs in the sauce is a must. They come out so tender as opposed to cooking in the oven or in a frying pan. Awesome!!

text:
I make this in the crockpot and it's pretty tasty. I always brown my meatballs before adding to a sauce - browning the meat adds extra flavour. I have made this twice, the first time using the ingredients listed served with pasta and it got a solid 4* rating. The second time I was making a healthier dinner so used turkey mince, less bread crumbs and served it with a salad. Due to making it the first time as is I also knew to add some more spices and herbs as well as increasing the amount of garlic for added flavour for the second time around, so it was probably a combination of those additions as well as using turkey that gives my adjusted version a 5* rating. Will be making again.

I didn't change a thing and the family *loves* it. I sometimes cook for my 2-3 adult brothers (#3 is rarely in town, so he doesn't count for much) and my elderly mother on family dinner night and this is a huge hit.

I used this recipe for my first attempt at making homemade spaghetti sauce.  It turned out wonderful. My boys, who are not huge fans of spaghetti, loved it. text:
I followed the suggestions of many other reviewers. For the meatballs, I used 1 lb. 93% ground turkey and 1 lb. mild Italian sausage turkey and seasoned  breadcrumbs and let the breadcrumbs soak in about 3/4c of milk BEFORE adding them to the meat and baked in 350 for 20 minutes. For the sauce, I didn't have whole peeled tomatoes so used 2 cans crushed tomatoes instead.I added two small cans of tomato sauce. With the the basil, I also used italian seasoning too.

text:
Very good. Very soft and tender meatballs. I took the advice of others and added more seasonings to the meatballs and the sauce. I used half seasoned breadcrumbs and half fresh breadcrumbs, also added a little milk. I lightly browned meatballs in skillet and then transferred with drippings to sauce and simmered covered with sauce for 30 minutes. They were done and really tender and moist. Maybe add some Italian herb seasoning and red pepper flakes next time. 
Thanks for a great recipe and the reviews/suggestions that accompany it.

-Arie

text:
I made this in my slow cooker in the morning so it could cook all day on low. I put the meatballs and Italian sausage in it at that time too. The flavor the sauce got from the meat cooking in it was delicious. I used two 28 oz cans of crushed tomatoes, one 28 can of tomato sauce and two cans of tomato paste. I also cut the garlic back to two cloves and found that was plenty for us. I left out they bay leaf. I will definitely make this recipe again.

country:
None
text:
This recipe tasted just like my Italian mother's meatballs and sauce!  She would add beef neck bones that were browned and added in the sauce to simmer.  However, I have a hard time finding neck bones, so I add a small steak that has a bone or a small bone-in beef shank. Brown the steak first and then add to the sauce to simmer.  Add browned meatballs later and do not over cook the meatballs in the sauce.  Delicious recipe!  Thanks for the recipe! Robin

text:
Excellent recipe.  I was really surprised that the meatballs stayed together.  That being said, next time I am going to cut back on the bread crumbs as the meatballs were almost too sturdy.  Also, using whole tomatoes is a big no-no when you have picky eaters in the family.  Right before I put the meatballs in the sauce, I pureed the tomatoes in a blender for a couple of seconds.  Tasted delicious and the kids ate it!

thegourmetrose

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is definitely a 5 star spaghetti sauce as is. It has been my favorite go to recipe for years. On occasion when I don't have time to make meatballs, I just add 1 to 2 lbs ground beef and put in 1 tablespoon each of parsley and Parmesan cheese in to the sauce. I always use a wooden spoon to stir any tomato based sauce (as recommended by an Italian friend) as metal or plastic can transfer a funny taste due to acidity in tomatoes. I use agave instead of sugar. I slow cook it for 3 to 4 hours on low after I reduce it some as the whole tomatoes are full of water and can make it a tad runny (without reducing). I always triple the batch and when it is cooled off I put in gallon freezer bags for the days we want a home cooked dinner and don't have much time. I love making either homemade French bread or focaccia bread with this spaghetti. Wonderful!

text:
I must say...I have been searching for a meatball recipe that will satisfy my rather picky (when it comes to meatballs) husband and THIS IS IT!  My eight year old said it was the best recipe she's had in months :-), and I loved it!  I think the key may be the homemade sauce which was simple but delicious and infused with the meatball flavor.   I admit that I actually joined allrecipes just to rate this one- it is my first review though I frequent the site.   I am not an expert chef so did not dare make any major changes except that I omitted the sugar and the tomato paste as we don't like sweet sauces and I added some salt to the meatball mix; so if you are like me in disliking sweetness, well, then don't add sugar or paste!   Otherwise I followed directions- I did not pre-cook the meatballs but added directly to the sauce as specified and they turned out perfectly.  This would make a great make ahead meal too.  I have found my spaghetti and meatball recipe- thanks!

This is the first time I made my own spaghetti sauce. It was so easy I will never again buy sauce from a jar! While I had tried making homemade meatballs in the past, it was time consuming so I rarely made homemade meatballs. Not the case with this recipe. I think the meatballs and sauce were even better when warmed up for left overs a couple days later. Yum!

text:
Really 4 1/2.  The only thing I did to make it my favorite was to split half lean ground beef, and half ground pork.  Don't listen to those people who say to brown the meatballs before putting in the sauce.  NOT browning them allows the flavors of the sauce to really get in there.  We are a carnivore family, so I took the other half pounds of beef and pork, and browned them with the onion and garlic to start the sauce.  Other than that, this was excellent.  I have no idea why anyone would want to buy store bought pasta sauce.  This is too easy, and tastes much, much, much fresher.

text:
I followed the instructions almost exactly. I wanted smaller meatballs, so I ended up with 20. I had diced tomatoes with Italian seasoning on hand so I used those instead of the whole ones. The only other difference was that once my husband and I were raving over this on hoagie rolls as a wonderful meatball sandwich, I realized that I forgot the tomato paste at the end. We had plenty of leftovers so I added most of the can afterwards. We had it with noodles the next day and both agreed that it had too much tomato flavor for us. That's our preference though, so this recipe still gets a solid 5 stars. In the future, I will omit the tomato paste. Other than that, this was fabulous! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I substituted ground turkey for the beef and used Ezekiel bread to make the meatballs for a healthier choice. We had another family over for a dinner party - their kids ages 4 and 2 were asking for seconds! And in my opinion, if the kids like it it, it must be good! It was a hit with my husband and kids as well. Good bye Ragu and Prego! The only downfall to this recipe is the time it takes to simmer the sauce. But it's not like you can't be doing something else while that's going on. So if you have the time this recipe is a must!
