text:
My husband is Italian, and we decided to try this recipe just for the meatballs, and with slight modification.  He and the rest of the family loved it!  We didn't have breadcrumbs on hand, so we substituted with crumbled saltine crackers.  We also added 1 mild Italian sausage to the 1 lb ground beef.  The Italian sausage definitely adds great flavor!!  We made the meatballs a little smaller, so they would soak up the sauce (our own) better.  Delicious!

Display Name:
cheetaah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now my go-to recipe! I do make double or more because it freezes well, and do the meatballs separately, bake and freeze in freezer bags. It freezes better that way, meatballs don't fall apart.  The only changes I make to the meatballa are to sub pork for 1/3 of the beef, and add a bit of milk to the meatball mixture for moisture.  For the sauce I halve the tomato paste and like to add some other herbs sometimes, especially parsley and marjoram or oregano, but I let the basil carry the flavor.  The sauce is good on it's own, but REALLY good once simmered with the meatballs.  I made around 10 pints of sauce today, meatballs last week.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this a few times.  The latest was the best! I kept the sauce virtually the same, except I had fresh basil and so I used it (3x fresh to dried ratio).  Meatballs-- I did 1/2 lean ground beef, 1/2 italian sausage.  I added 1 T fresh thyme, 4.5 T fresh parsley (because they were on hand), 1/2 c. ital bread crumbs and 1/2 c. panko-- again, because that's just what I had..  I did sear the meatballs before adding to the sauce-- but I've cooked without searing, and without the other changes, and it's just a lovely sauce.  Kids & hubby loved it.  And it freezes well.

Play with this recipe-- you won't be disappointed!

text:
Good base recipe; i'd have given it 4 but found it salty; omitted salt on the second go. 
I made this two ways the first time .. 
one batch I added the meatballs to cook in the sauce directly 
and for the other batch baked the balls in the oven @ 350 for 40 or so minutes.. 
I liked the baked meatballs better - they caramelized adding more flavor.

Second time around 1/2 pork 1/2 beef mix; added a pinch of crushed chili ppr to the meatball mix; omitted salt; reduced sugar to 1/4 tsp and fresh basil to the sauce.. fantastic - will stick with renewed version for a five star meal.

text:
Instead of 1 of the cans of whole tomatoes, I used 14oz stewed tomatoes and 14oz can diced or chopped tomatoes.  I also added  little smoked sausage and bell pepper.  Also, it needed about 2T white sugar and 1T Worcestershire sauce .  Blend after cooking for smooth texture.  If not, just leave it chunky.  This is, by far, the best marinara sauce.

i was hesitant to make a two and a half hour spaghetti sauce, because i think prego tastes better than a lot of italian restaurant dishes, but i dont know if i will EVER use prego again!!!
this was the BEST BEST BEST spaghetti ive ever had! i wasnt too crazy about the meatballs, but hubby raved about them too.  
the sauce was perfect the next day, made mini pizzas, and used as a dipping sauce for mozzerella sticks.
i cant begin to explain how perfect all the spices were. loved it, next time i may use 2 cans of tomato paste to make it a tad bit thicker, but still, the sauce was WAY BETTER THAN AUTHENTIC ITALIAN RESTAURANTS.
thank you so much for a great keeper

I've made this recipe over 20 times now and have made minor changes, ie. using organic plum tomatoes over regular, using more onions and garlic, using loose ground beef over meatballs, and simmering with cooked pasta. text:
I have been making this recipe for over a year now.  I used to love my moms spaghetti and meatballs, but she died with her recipe :(  I searched here for a recipe I could try and found this one.  I stick to the original recipe pretty much, except lately I have been using diced tomatoes just because it's easier than the whole.  I also add a pinch of baking soda to cut the acid some (a trick I learned on the internet) and I add some brown sugar to sweeten it up some.  I just love the flavor of this sauce!  The meatballs always come out perfect, and since they are cooked in the sauce....so easy.  I recommend this recipe wholeheartedly!

text:
Ummm, Wow! I honestly am not a big fan of spaghetti, but I occasionally get in the mood for it so I tried this. It's wonderful! I did change some things though. I made a meat sauce instead of meatballs. I browned the meat with the dried parsely, black pepper, and garlic powder. Then set it aside. I then followed the directions for the sauce. When it was time to add in the meatballs (in my case, sauteed ground beef), I added the meat and other ingredients as directed, plus grated parmesan. I then let everything simmer. No bread crumbs were used at all. The result was savory, italian meat sauce. This is a winner!

FINALLY!!! A homemade sauce that turned out perfect!!!  I have been trying different recipes for years and this one is a keeper....for sure!  I made a VERY slight change...I sauted the onions first and then added the garlic after the onions cooked for a while so that the garlic wouldn't burn.  I also took out the bay leaf after simmering for 90 minutes...before adding the final ingredients.

I did not use the meatball recipe though...but it looks good! Thank you Jeremy!!!

text:
I have never rated a recipe before, but after making this, I wanted to write one.  This spaghetti sauce with meatballs is delicious!! One of the best I have ever had. I used 2 cans of 28oz crushed tomatoes, as well as 1 can of whole tomatoes.  I used about 1.5 tsp of salt, and 1 tsp of sugar.  I also used fresh basil. For the meatballs, I used 1.5lb of beef, and used about a cup of breadcrumbs and 2 eggs.  It really was so good, I can't wait to have the leftovers tonight!!! Thank you for the wonderful recipe!

This was my first homemade spaghetti sauce. I didn't make the meatballs, used ground beef instead. I omitted the sugar (I don't like sweet sauce) and added about a teaspoon of oregano and a can of crushed tomatoes. I also put half of the sauce in the blender when it was finished to smooth the sauce out a little. This recipe was easy and way better than store bought sauce. I will definitely make this recipe again.

text:
AWESOME SAUCE!!!! This is my new fav recipe, out-beating "Worlds best pasta sauce" on all recipes. I made a few modifications: 1/4 cup of parmesan cheese,chili-powder, tumeric,garlic powder, and garlic, and seasoned homemade breadcrumbs instead of the plain. For the sauce I used 1 tomatoe in place of the canned, 1/4 cup of rice vinegar which gave it more flavor then water, I'm half Asian Indian so I have to add chili-powder, tumeric,garlic powder, and garlic to everything! basil,bay-leaf,oregano went in too. I formed 14 meatballs and dropped them raw into the sauce (i never cook them before too much work and the meatballs soak up the flavor of the sauce)I even added a bit of milk since another reviewer said something about adding milk to thicken/ make the sauce creamier. Served with fettuccine pasta cuz that's all I had. My sister and brother love it!! :D

text:
I selected this recipe based on its' ratings and makeup (meatballs) and and was not dissapointed whatsover! I had considered "bottled" sauce but opted for the "made-from-scratch" variety. Frankly, I was concerned 'bout not searing the meat, but highly recommend that you follow the recipe as listed! In fact, I cooked the sauce for my colleagues and to a person they raved about it. I transferred finished sauce to a stone, slow-cooker for initial refrigeration and for ease of serving. I reheated on high for a couple of hrs and then reduced to "warm" to ensure that the ingredents fully integrated and that the meatballs were done. Good eating!

Delish! 

Of course, I made a couple of a tweaks to make this even more healthy! First, I did not add the olive oil - added 1/4 c of water instead and used the juice from the canned tomatoes. 

I also used a dropper full of concentrated liquid Stevia instead of the sugar. 

This was crazy easy, no preservatives and everyone how has tasted this (brought it to the office) was amazed at how good it was! I'll be doing it again here this week!

text:
Yummy sauce. I add italian seasoning to the sauce and skip the sugar. For the meatballs i use 1/2 ground beef 1/2 ground pork, the cheese, an egg, uncooked oatmeal, garlic powder, parsley and a little italian seasoning. I put them uncooked into the sauce but it simmers in a crockpot for 4 hours on low. They aren't mushy then.

text:
I saute the onion and garlic I used 2 can of diced tomatoes 2 can of tomatoe sauce, 2 tsp italian sesoning 1 tsp oregano 1 tsp parsley, 1 Tsp pesto sauce 1 can tomatoe paste 2 tsp brown sugar 2 tsp of ccomplete sesoning 1 tsp basil 1 tsp of ground bay leaf and  salt and pepper  to taste  about 30 min into cooking the sauce .I blend the sauce in the blender to smooth it out.Baked the meatball in the oven for 15 min,finsh cooking it in the sauce.This is a delicious sauce that i have used on many ocassion thx Jeremy

text:
My family and  I love the recipe... easy, fast and full of great flavors. The only recommendations I have are: (1) substitute the dried parsley and basil with fresh products, (2) use organic garlic cloves (they pack more punch!) and (3) use a good quality grated parmesan with a good moisture level (if you can!).

text:
Fantastic simple sauce and really easy to prepare. I did as others  have suggested and used only one can whole tomatoes and one can crushed. For the meatballs I did 1/2 lb ground beef and 1/2 lb hot grated Italian sausage. I also added 1/2 t. of crushed red pepper flakes to the mix. I also did one half of the meatballs by browning in a pan and adding to sauce and the other half I baked in the over @ 350 for 25 minutes before adding to the sauce. In the future I will bake them before adding... I like the crispy outside... Loved both of these items and glad others have done the trial and error before I got to this... I gave it 5 stars after the changes and it was easy to make.

text:
I tried this recipe for the first time on Christmas. I've never made my own sauce before. The sauce was so good!!!  I used whole peeled tomatoes.  I also put all the ingredients in at the same time.  After it simmered for about four hours, I ran it through a blender.  I then added the meatballs and simmered for an additional six hours.  The more days that pass, the better the sauce is. For the meat balls I used half beef ad half ground sausage-delish!  Several people asked for the recipe!

Display Name:
NJladi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so simple I had to try it - with the following changes: I one can of diced tomatoes and 1 can of Italian tomatoes, diced fine in the blender, about 1 teaspoon each of oregano, marjoram and Cajon spice; and 1/2 cup fresh parsley, 3/4 cup diced celery, 1/2 cup diced carrot, and about 1.5 - 2 teaspoons black mustard seeds. I sauteed the spices, herbs and seeds along with the vegetables in olive oil before adding the tomatoe ingredients. I measure in the palm of my hand so the above measure can be decreased or increased to taste. I also added about 1/2 teaspoon of cayenne pepper for a little kick. Growing up with Italian food I also used this sauce (without the meatballs) baked with chicken topped with sliced mozzarella cheese one night and on Friday heated the sauce and added shrimp for about 5 minutes to serve over pasta - fabulous.  There are so many things you can do with a basic sauce and it's fun to experiment. Buon appetito!

This recipe is great! I have never made meatballs before, but they were wonderful. I didn't have breadcrumbs so I used saltine crackers that I put through the food processor. I also added rosemary and red pepper flakes to the meatball mixture. I rolled the meatballs in the cracker crumbs and lightly fried in olive oil before adding to the spaghetti sauce to cook the rest of the way. I also added fresh pesto the the sauce right before serving. Delish!

text:
I've made this twice now.    First time: I quadrupled the recipe for a large family gathering and used 3 lbs ground beef plus 1 lb ground pork to the meatball mixture.  I also added a little more parmesan cheese (1/4 cup?) to the meatballs.  The sauce was made per the posted recipe (I may have added an extra teaspoon of sugar and a little Italian seasoning).  It was great!  The meatballs had a great taste and my company raved about it.  Second time: Made the meatballs with only beef and added a little more parmesan again.  Followed the recipe other than that.  I also made the sauce the same way as the first time.  The meatballs came out VERY bland, and the sauce is decent.  I will use this recipe again, but I will always add ground pork to the meatballs.  The sauce smells like my Italian grandmother's, but doesn't quite taste the same.  Don't get me wrong, it's good.  There's just some something missing...almost there, though.  Maybe a few red pepper flakes?

Not a better recipe out there. I use whole San marzano tomato's only- nothing is better and I double the garlic- add a couple more bay leaves and double the basil-i use fresh leaves and roll them and slice. I put a tbsp of sugar in and sometimes a tiny bit more.  Put in the crock pot for 4-6 hours and let the tomatoes break down. I also add everything at once....meatballs the last hour or so. Meatball recipe is perfect! I make this ALL the time-its a HUGE hit and you cant beat it.

text:
This was my first time making spaghetti and meatballs, and possibly my first time making spaghetti sauce from scratch. I never want to go back to the jar sauce! This was awesome, and really quite easy. It takes awhile to make, but most of it is not active prep/cooking time. I used a couple fresh tomatoes in addition to the canned (had some I needed to use), added some salt to the sauce and a little bit of salt-free italian seasoning in addition to the parsley and basil. I also substituted some mild italian sausage for some of the ground beef (about 1/4 of it). It was delicious!

userID:
3156254
Display Name:
Brooke Salazar
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5

13
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3278934.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this sauce twice.   The first time I pretty much followed it exactly.  I didn't make the meatballs- we just added cooked ground beef.  First time around I tasted the sauce while it was cooking and it was SO BLAND!  3/4 tsp basil for all those tomatoes seems like nothing.  And I don't understand why there are so many good reviews because as written this is a very bland sauce.  I had to add extra basil, oregano, onion and garlic.  Second time around I added 1 bell pepper( I double the recipe and freeze some), and all the same extras from the first time around.   I also prefer a smoother sauce so I use one can of tomatoe puree and one can of crushed tomatoes.  If anything, this is a good base.  I will continue to make it, only because I prefer to make things from scratch and it's cheaper.

text:
Best spaghetti and meatballs I've ever had! I forgot to saute the olive oil, onions, and minced garlic, but it didn't matter it still turned out great. I did add some cut zucchini which made it sooooo good! The meatballs were really good, but I did double the parmesan cheese because my fiance wanted them to be cheesey. The best part, is that because I made the 6 servings and there is only 3 people in my family, there is a bunch left. I will never buy jarred sauce again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife has been making fantastic meatballs for years so I tried this recipe to see if it gave hers a run for it's money.  I was very dissapointed by the meatballs and the sauce.  1st of all, the bread crumbs are way to much unless you're looking for the consistency of meatloaf.  I'd suggest using a 1/4 cup of bread crumbs per pound of meat.  2nd, the meatballs need to be browned before dropping raw meat into the sauce. Most of the recipes I've tried with this many 4.5 star reviews have been fantastic.   I'll pass on this one.

text:
I only made the meatballs so thats all I can rate.  I really enjoyed this recipe because it is similar to my mothers recipe.  Although a bit bland, it is a great way to start with a meatball and using it again and adding the flavors that suit you. I followed the recipe "to a T" and thought that the meatballs could use a bit more doctoring up.   The second time I made this I added 1/4 tsp. garlic to the original recipe, use the three meat combo traditional to Italian meatballs, more parmesan cheese and 1/8 tsp. of water so that the meat wouldn't dry out. Today I am going to try the sauce portion of this recipe.  Thank you Jeremy for sharing this recipe!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this 5 stars after tasting just the meatballs. My young boys are very picky eaters and not only did all 3 of them eat the meatballs (a shock in itself!), but they all wanted seconds and were upset to find none were left (my husband and I had eaten them all). This NEVER happens.  I made 2 changes to the original recipe: I used turkey burger instead of ground beef and whole grain Cream of Wheat instead of breadcrumbs (I got the cereal idea from Swedish Meatballs 1 by Jessica). Thanks to other reviewers who mentioned turkey burger gets too dry with breadcrumbs, I used maybe 1/2 cup of cereal instead of 1 cup.  I put them in a saucepan with jarred marinara and they were fantastic! No browning, no mess; perfect.  Today I'm trying them in the crockpot.   I haven't made the sauce yet (did I mention my kids were picky eaters?) but I plan to, and I suspect it will be delicious.

text:
This was the first time I have made spaghetti from scratch and it turned out delicious. For the meatballs I didn't have ground beef, so instead I used ground pork infused with sage and turkey, 1/2 lb each. I added some minced celery and fresh parsley instead of the dry. I also added 1/2 c. milk in case the turkey would dry out the meatball. The only other change I made was that I used a hand blender to break down the chunks of tomato, or else I would never hear the end of it from my husband that there were giant chunks of tomato! Excellent dish:)

text:
I love this recipe!  The meatballs are divine. However, I do cut the salt in half, and cook the meatballs and sauce all together.  I'm sure its better if you let the sauce simmer for 90 minutes, but I don't have time.  It tastes great even after 30 minutes or until meatballs are cooked through. I print this recipe off and give with the olive oil, wine, pasta pot, and spaghetti as a bridal shower gift.  I used to make a homemade spaghetti sauce with ground beef, but it doesn't take much longer to make the meatballs.  This is in the regular rotation and I don't make my mother's recipe anymore....shhh don't tell her!

country:
None
text:
I rated this 4 out 5 due to the changes I needed to make.  MEATBALLS: I mixed one tablespoon of Italian Seasoning II (from this site) to the bread crumbs, 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1/2 cup milk beat in with the egg.  The meat balls came out moist and flavorful.  (It's not a bad idea to mix ground beef with pork, increase Parmesan to 1/4 cup and use crushed Ritz crackers as the bread crumb base.)  SAUCE: I used two 28 oz cans of chopped tomatoes, no bay leaf, a pinch of nutmeg and decreased salt in half.  The sauce did not come out too sweet with the tsp of sugar used or too acidic for my taste.  Next time I will add more garlic (2 - 4 extra cloves) and sliced mushrooms (1 lb).  NOODLES: Poured meatball sauce over five cheese tortellini from Costco (which cooks in 3 - 5 mins). OTHER: Served with toasted garlic bread on the side.

country:

text:
Made this for the first time last night and the sauce came out okay.  My only complaint was that the sauce was WAY too salty, although reading back over the recipe, I see I put 2 TABLEspoons instead of 2 TEAspoons, so that would do it.  I did make some changes: For the meatballs I used half ground beef and half spicy italian sausage.  I used crackers instead of breadcrumbs and fresh parsley instead of dried.  These were EXCELLENT!  For the sauce I substituted 14oz of the whole tomatoes for 14oz of diced.  I think I will do half and half next time because I like the texture of diced better.  I also used fresh basil instead of dried and added fresh italian parley.  I had a big bowl of both herbs chopped and ready to go and added as I felt the sauce needed.  Ended up adding way more than 3/4 teaspoon, but it was worth it :)  When adding the tomato paste at the end the sauce thickened up really nicely and came out with a great constancy.  The meatballs were really tasty and even though we added way too much salt, the base of the sauce was still really delicious.  I will definitely have this again.

userID:
2240773
Display Name:
Angie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/103718.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I had to modify based on what I had here at home, but it was awesome! I accidentally used 1 cup of Parmesan instead of 1 tbsp. Soooo good, though! Here is what I did:  used 1 lb. ground sirloin for the meatballs. Took 4 slices of bread (crusts off) and made bread crumbs with some garlic powder, salt & pepper mixed in. Mixed it all with the ground meat, egg, and 1/2 cup milk. I did brown them on all sides and removed them with a slotted spoon and then sauteed the garlic & onions in the meat drippings. I didn't have 90 minutes to let it all simmer, so I added in one 28 oz. can of crushed tomatoes, some dried basil, and a tsp. of kosher salt. Mixed it up and then put the meatballs in the sauce and let it simmer 30 minutes on low heat while covered. The last 10 minutes of simmering, I added in about 1/2 cup of a good chianti.  Made the spaghetti, drained it, and added in 1 tbsp. butter to the noodles before mixing in the sauce. It was absolutely delicious! Didn't use any sugar or tomato paste, and the meatballs were almost falling apart they were so tender and juicy with cheese starting to pop out from where I used a cup instead of a tablespoon - absolutely amazing dinner!

text:
Thanks for a great recipe - simple, reliable and delicious. It's becoming a weekly regular and always just enough meatballs left for my husband and I to have sandwiches the next day. I sometimes spice up sauce with with a tsp or so of chili flakes. I cut the total time by starting with the sauce and making the meatballs while it simmers. If time is short, I trim the first simmer time from 90 to 60 minutes, then added the meatballs for the another 30 minutes.

text:
I made these with my sister for our Italian Christmas Eve feast. They were delicious and very close to my grndma's recipe. I am giving this 4 stars rather than 5 because i made the first batch with lean ground beef and found them to be kind of tough. I made the next 2 batches with 80/20 ground beef and they were much more tender. THis does not affect the rating bc it was my modification but we added both minced 1/2 an onion and 1/4 milk to each batch which made them a little mushy. I would use one or the other next time to avoid this texture.  I used traditional Prego sauce instead of making our own (family preference) and they were a hit! Thanks!!!

text:
This is the best spaghetti sauce!  I have tried and tried to make a spaghetti sauce that was something special  - and this is what I was looking for!  I followed the recipe exactly and then at the end mashed up the sauce with a potato masher to get the big chunks out.  Every time I had tried to make a sauce before, it would be a bit watery and not "balanced."  This one has the perfect thick texture and it is the perfect rich blend of savory and sweet to cancel out any acidity from the tomatoes.  I WILL make this again...and again...and again!

text:
My little brother requested spaghetti and meatballs for his birthday dinner. He is much younger than me (9) and like most little kids picky but this was a hit and even my little sister (10) who won't eat anything had seconds of the meatballs. The recipe appealed to the adults to getting the stamp of approval from my roommate who works as a chef in an upscale restaurant in my town. I did make a few changes though. Instead of whole tomatoes I used diced, I used 8 garlic cloves, I added all the spices right away, I left out the bay leaf as I had forgotten to pick some up. I used about 2 tbsp of pepper, as well as cayenne pepper. Basil was fresh from my wonderful little herb garden. After simmering for 90 minutes I took a suggestion from below and blended about half of the sauce in the blender to smooth it out. After doing this there was no need for tomato paste as it was quite thick already. Very good!

text:
I really wanted to love this but thought it was only OK after following the recipe exactly as written.  The meatballs were a bit doughy and tasteless.  I'd half the breadcrumbs and add 1/2 cup diced onion and 2 cloves minced fresh garlic.  Also, perhaps 1 tsp italian seasoning.  The sauce was almost a bit too thick and sweet.  I'd forego the tomato paste and substitute with a can of tomato sauce so that there is plenty of sauce for the pasta.  I'd also hold off on the sugar until the sauce is cooked down and add only if you find the sauce to tangy.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I'll never try another recipe after this one.  The first time I made this dish I used 1 lb. of ground beef, but the meatballs were very bland and didn't cook all the way in the sauce as the recipe calls for. The second time I followed the advice of others and used 1/2 lb. of beef, a little more than 1/2 lb. of italian sausage, and I fried them for about 10 minutes before adding them to the sauce. What a difference! They were phenomenal! Also, I'm not sure how much of a difference this made, but I used fresh herbs instead of dried.

country:
None
text:
I made a couple chages to this recipe after tasting it an hour into simmering. I thought it was tasting way too tomatoey so I added 2 TBLS brown sugar and 2 tsp itailan style seasoning. That did the trick. So the changes I made from the beginning were: I used brown surgar instead of white. I pureed the tomatoes, I didn't have tomatoe paste so I used an 8 oz can of roasted garlic tomatoe sauce and 3 TBLS of oats that I blended with the tomatoes to thicken the sauce. I followed the meatballs exactly and they had such a great aroma but kind of lacked in taste. I will play around with more spices the next time I make this. As written this recipe is a 3 or 4, with the changes I made I would give it 5 stars.

Update: I made the sauce along with the meatballs and this was a hit! I added some cherry tomatoes and fresh rosemary that were leftover from a previous snack, and simmered for 60 minutes as per instructions, then added the meatballs/basil/tomato paste, and simmered another 60 minutes. The meatballs came out perfect (I made 8 large meatballs instead of 12). I can't believe I didn't make the sauce with these the first time!

text:
This was pretty good but the sauce itself is very plain.  I added 3/4 tsp of italian seasoning, used 1 TB and 1 tsp fresh basil in place of the dried and added 1/2 tsp of red pepper flakes.  I was afraid that the meatballs would be dry so I added 1/2 cup of milk to the bread crumbs and let them soak for a minute.  They were quite moist this way.  This is a great base recipe that you can play around with.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm spoiled having grown up in a household where Grandma spent an entire two days making a vat of homemade spaghetti sauce. This recipe is OK for a quick fix - but nothing beats slow cooked Italian perfection when there is ample time (but who has ample time these days?). Was pleased with the flavor considering the short cooking time - which us busy moms LOVE.  Can't make meatballs though without the classic combo of the three meats - ground beef (at least 85% fat), ground pork and ground veal.  Makes SUCH a huge difference in the texture, taste and consistency of the meatballs. I also increased the amount of parm cheese (used fresh grated)along with some home grown basil. Thanks for the quick dinner fix! Was really ready in 1/2 hour...

text:
This is the first Spaghetti Sauce that I ever attempted!  I was a little hesitant at first but the results were yummy!  I've made this recipe several times and its soooooo much better than jar sauce, but yet soooooo easy to make!  The only changes that I made were: I chopped the whole tomatoes first and then added 1 28 oz. can of tomatoe sauce.  Without the added sauce it was just too thick.  It makes so much that I always have leftovers to freeze!  So when you make this recipe, you are actually making at least 2 meals!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good.  My only modification was to use one can of crushed tomatoes in place of one of the cans of whole tomatoes.  However the tomatoes broke down just fine so maybe next time I will just use the whole tomatoes as called for and use a potato masher to break up the chunks.  In the meatballs I did also increase the parmesan chesse to about 1/4 cup and garlic powder to maybe 3 tablespoons and added a little chicken stock.  I made this in my slow cooker and cooked the sauce for three hours before adding the meatballs and remaining ingredients and cooked for about two more hours.  A great classic comfort food recipe that is easy to make all day in the slow cooker.

Thanks again for such a great recipe, boiling the meatballs in the sauce is the secret to making this sauce amazing. :)

text:
One word...delicious! This recipe is simply the BEST Spaghetti Sauce with Meatballs that I've ever had.  This has become a staple in our family.  It's inexpensive to prepare, because most of the ingrediants you should already have on hand.  I can't say enough good things.  I've made it with the addition of sauteed vegetables and without and it's amazing either way.  I follow the recipe exactly, and I cook the meatballs in the sauce as opposed to browning them in the frying pan.  I grew up eating them like that and i think this way is MUCH better...but the choice is yours.  You've got to try it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/169126.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I'm not a spaghetti fan.  However, the rest of my family loves it, so I tried this recipe on them.  I added more garlic to the meatball mixture than called for (we love garlic) and some dry Italian seasoning as well, since many complained of the meatballs being bland.  I made smaller meatballs, so I got more than 12.  I baked them at 350 for about 15 minutes (I just can't bring myself to throw them in the sauce raw...personal preference here, so no affecting the rating).  In the sauce, I used 1 can whole tomatoes and 1 can crushed tomatoes (but I ended up using a potato masher on them anyway, so next time I will probably use either 2 cans crushed or petite diced).  I also used dried Italian seasoning in place of the dried basil because I felt like it :P.  When I tasted the sauce, I found that it was slightly acidic, so I followed the advice of another reviewer and used about 3/4 tsp. of baking soda...it worked perfectly.  Foamed a little, at first, but after that went away, the sauce was wonderful.  I served over Spaghetti Rigati (I think...the kind with ridges).  I even ate a little!  Thanks for posting!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family LOVES LOVES LOVES this recipe!!  It is SOOOO easy because you don't have to cook the meatballs other than in the sauce (browning first can be such a mess!).  I crush seasoned croutons for the breadcrumbs (onion and garlic flavor).  Also, once the sauce is finished simmering (right before I add the meatballs), I use a potato masher to crush the whole tomatoes.  Makes the sauce extra yummy and gives it a smoother consistency.

Loved the consistency of the sauce.  It really is one of the better sauces around.  The meatballs were so-so for me.  A few changes though - I only had one can of tomatoes so I used 2 small cartons of passatta in place of the second can and cut back the salt to 1tsp. I also added some veggies.  Will be making this again.

text:
This was the best sauce and meatballs I have ever made. I do have to admit, I took liberty with some additional spices for the meat balls and added cream to keep them moist.  I used fresh minced garlic, and minced fresh oregano, basil and some time and added to the meatballs. I also browned my meatballs in EVOO before adding to the sauce. I did not use sugar. I made the sauce just as directed but added fresh chopped basil.  I used half of the recommend onion.  Also I used two turkish bay leaves.  They have such a beautiful aroma.  Instead of Parmesan cheese I used Asiago, Romano and shredded chedder cheeses.  Absolutly fabulous base for a recipe.  Thank you!

text:
these were so good! yum.. I kind of used the ingredients and then improvised a little. I used shredded cheddar instead of parmesan, added some worcestershire sauce and, believe it or not, about a tbsp of sour cream and onion mix. And oh, I added a dash of milk as well because it seemed a little dry. They tasted like heaven! I did the same thing with the sauce. I added balsamic vinegar, worcestershire sauce and stock. It was the best meatball recipe I have ever used! I will keep this forever :)

text:
Fantastic meal!! My husband and I usually don't like meatballs, but I made it because my girls do. He and I ended up really enjoying it! Here are my changes: used cans of tomato sauce instead of whole tomatoes, used only 1.5 tsps of salt but was still a bit too salty for my taste, had no bay leaves but didn't seem to make a difference, in the meatballs I used ground up italian flavored croutons like someone else mentioned, I did not use egg but I added a TBSP each of tom. sauce, olive oil, and water, I also browned meatballs a bit in olive oil. It was a very rich sauce b/t the oil and the meat but just delicious!!!

text:
This was my 1st time making homemade sauce and meatballs. It was surprisingly easy to make and although I was a bit nervous about the meatballs cooking through, they turned out DELICIOUS!! I did make a few changes as recommended by other viewers. MEATBALLS: used 1 lb beef and added 4 oz of ground pork. Used 2 Tbs Parm. SAUCE: used only ONE can large peeled tomatoes and added 2 small cans crushed tomatoes. After simmer, added small can of tomato sauce with the tomato paste. Also added 1 tsp. italian seasoning and 1 tsp. garlic powder. 

Boy this was good. Can't wait to make again for more people!!!

text:
If you want moist meatballs, then you should BROWN them in EVOO o all sides ....THEN you throw them in the sauce to finish cooking.It seals in the juices! I also SOAK the bread crumbs in milk for a short while then squeeze out the excess. In addition to my additions (hehe)Use the veal, pork, beef mixture and you are sure to be guaranteed a moist DELICIOUS meatball! Anyways- YES -GREAT RECIPE!

My review is only for the sauce as I did not have time to make the meatballs. I just used premade meatballs. The sauce was awesome!  So much better than a jarred sauce.  I made exactly as written except increased the sugar to more like 1 tablespoon to cut down on more of the acidity.  After the sauce had simmered for the 90 minutes I emersion blended the sauce to make a smooth consistency because the tomatoes were still whole. Then I whisked in the tomato paste.

text:
I can only rate half the recipe which were the meatballs! These were the best meatballs I've made thus far! I was very leary about the lack of ingredients. The recipe did not call for onion, which I have always put into my meatballs prior...well never again. These meatballs had so much flavor AS IS!!! I buy my hamburger meat in bulk and make a TON (I multiplied this recipe by 3) of meatballs to freeze for future uses. I did have to bake them since I was not putting them into a sauce to cook. These were phenomenal! So juicy, moist tender and FULL of Flavor! 
I will use this as my meatball recipe from here on out!

text:
This recipe was absolutely fantastic.  I have been looking for a "homemade" spaghetti sauce for quite a while.  I used my own canned whole tomatoes (2 quarts) changed the measurements accordingly.  It is even better the next day.  I made it like the recipe with the following additions:  extra sugar to balance out the acidity of the tomatoes.  No added salt as there was some in the canned tomatoes. I also added dried basil and dried oregano as well as garlic powder.  Next time I would add extra italian seasoning as well.  But a phenomenal recipe!!  This was just for the sauce as I just added ground beef...next time I will make the meatballs.

Really loved the sauce, though at first bite, it tasted a bit too salty.  The meatballs were tasty too, but a little greasy; I have to be sure to try a better quality of ground beef next time (any suggestions?).  I liked too that someone here suggested baking the meatballs instead of frying them; when I was cooking them, I felt like I burned them, so maybe baking is my answer.  Since I'm a single gal, this recipe produced plenty of leftovers, so I froze the meatballs in the sauce.  Looking forward to the leftovers this week!  Happy with the recipe overall, and I will definitely make again.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/72.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I hadn't made changes to the meatballs, I don't think they would have had much flavor, and I think they would have been too bread-y.  I used a little over a pound of ground beef, added some water, used a little UNDER a cup of seasoned breadcrumbs, added much more garlic powder and cheese.  I broiled them for a little over ten minutes before putting them in the pot because we like the flavor.  They tasted pretty good with my changes, but they were right on the cusp of being bland.  The sauce was good with the addition of oregano, garlic powder and a little extra sugar.  I didn't have/use the tomato paste, but found it thick enough if I mashed the tomatoes.  Used one can whole peeled tomatoes, one can diced.  Replaced onions with onion powder and used jarred minced garlic.  I liked the sauce a lot with the changes, and I'll probably make this again if I jazz up the meatballs a little more (probably with more garlic; we like garlic).  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I skipped the meatballs and made only the sauce because we were short on time and didn't really need the meat, so this is for the sauce portion only. I did make many changes according to other's suggestions and let me say this was awesome! I will make this recipe from now on (as long as I have the time). Here are some of the changes I made: added 2 celery stalks (chopped), used 1 (28 oz) can crushed tomatoes and 2 (14 oz) cans of diced tomatoes, a little extra sugar, added italian seasoning, green bell pepper, and a serrano pepper. I will avoid that jarred spaghetti sauce at all cost from now on, because this recipe was so easy and so delicious! Thank you Jeremy!

I gave this 4 stars because it's a great base, but I made modifications for my own tastes.  I doubled the recipe, and in addition added, 1.5c. chopped bell peppers, 1.5c mushrooms, and mixed the ground beef for the meatblass with 1lb ground turkey.  I browned the meatballs before putting them in the sauce to give them a bit more texture, and also added oregano and basil to the sauce.  I served it over spaghetti squash.  I was wonderful!

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a very easy recipe to make, especially since the meatballs do not have to be precooked.  I used 28 oz of crushed tomatoes and 28 oz of whole tomatoes, otherwise it would have been too chunky. Also, since I didn't have fresh bread crumbs, I used dry seasoned bread crumbs and added 1/2 cup of milk to give it some moisture.  The meatballs are large but cooked thoroughly in the sauce after only 30 minutes.  I added some extra seasonings to the sauce and the meatballs.  Next time I'll add a little more garlic.

This recipe is great. I used italian bread, added more garlic and 1/4c of milk to the meatballs.  I browned them first before putting them in the sauce.  My family is picky about tomatoes so I also blended them first and I left out the bay leaf.  My husband was very pleased! Wow! Now that's impressive.  I had double the meat so I made extra meatballs that I put in a baking dish and cooked at 350 in the oven.  I'm not sure how long.  I just kept checking it. As soon as I took them out, my husband immediately put them in a roll and ate them.  Success!

text:
This is fabulous!  I've been making a quickie spaghetti sauce (that is great when you need it quick) for a couple years and the flavor difference in this sauce is astounding!  My picky 2.5 yr old daughter even ate the meatballs (and she does NOT like meat!).  My picky 5yr old loved it and has already asked to have it for lunch tomorrow.  
I cut the salt in half (those canned tomatoes have a lot of salt already), used fresh parsley instead of dried, used my hand blender to make it a little more saucy and added some sliced crimini mushrooms about 10 minutes before done.  Great recipe and I will be making it again!  Thanks!

I thought this was very good, although I did make a few changes.  I took ANDREA-LEE's suggestion to use the wheat germ (thanks, btw!) and I also added some milk to the meatballs to help keep them moist.  After forming the balls, I lightly browned them in some olive oil before adding them to the sauce.
I also omitted the sugar from my sauce -- never understood adding that.  Yuck!

But, overall it was a great meal.  We served it over spaghetti squash instead of pasta for an even healthier meal.  :-)

text:
This is a great recipe.  I've made it twice... the first time, I thought the sauce was a little thin and I could have used more of it, so the second time I cut down on the olive oil, added more tomato paste, and made a batch and a half.  Delicious!  Also, I made the meatballs smaller than called for (I'm not sure they would cook in 30 minutes if bigger), divided them into single-serving sizes with sauce, and froze them.  They were even more delicious a month later than they were the frist night, and so easy to just defrost in the microwave after work.
